reviews.review: The dessert for the Hermitage meal. A short distance from the Church of the Spilled blood, this museum is a treat for art lovers. I found no long lines at the ticket booth nor large tourist groups in the galleries allowing you to enjoy these great works of art at leisure.Housed in the beautiful Mikhailovsky Palace this Museum exhibits an impressive collection of Russian art from early medieval Icons to the great 19th and 20th century paintings of Surkov, Vanetsov, Vrubel, Roerich, Goncharova Kandinsky to name a few.

Amazing art for all senses - a jewel!. Here you find Ilja Repin, Vruebel, everything. Also the special exhibitions are always wonderful. Reserve at least 2-3 hours, and do not go hungry or tired - it is huge! Thursday evenings are for free but also very busy.Do not miss this jewel for an art museum!

art collections in a beautiful palace. More do-able than the Hermitage, the collections here are fabulous - icons particularly stunning. Cheap little cafe on the premises, too, handy for tea & maybe a snack. There's even a post office there, too (we wasted ages looking for one in St P).
Student trip to museum. Lots things to see. There must be few hours time if you would like see everything. Our guide speaks English well and the tour were interesting.
Superb. On this museum you find Russian arts from mid XIX to XX. It has also a section about folk Russian art. It with a visit for knowing more about Russian painting and have great surprises.

Jewel of St. Petersburg. While the Hermitage is excellent, the State Museum is the ideal place to see any Russian painters or sculptors that you love. Exhibiting only Russian artists from different periods of Russia's history, this huge museum needs a large portion of your time. It's just that good.

Great Russian collection!. Mostly visited by me for Malevich Kandinsky and other modern painters who can really make changes in Russian art. Of course something old is great too.)Toilet is too dirty for such a great museum..(
Amazing museum. What a understated gem of a museum which houses the biggest collection of Russian art and the biggest secret is, it is not crowded

Excellent palace. This museum was once used by the erstwhile kings in the past, now maintained by the state. The interior paintings and carvings on the ceilings, walls and doors are simply superb. The craftsmen have extensively used gold to add lot of glitter to the carvings. Though in general the kings palace is very large, some of the rooms said to have been used by the family look to be compact. Anyway it's a reality and everyone visiting Russia must visit this place and enjoy the grandeur.

Great collection. This is a fantastic museum with a great collection of Russian art. We especially loved the Malevich and Kandinsky paintings and the works of some of the Russian Fauvre artists. This is a huge museum which, for some reason attracts only limited tourist interest which means one can walk straight in and purchase a ticket without any delay and the museum is quiet and uncrowded. The display of the art is also excellent. Definitely a place we would return to if we revisited St. Petersburg.

Definitely not second best. One hears so much about the Winter Palace and the Hermitage that it is easy to forget this wonderful museum. It was quite a revelation to us. Why had we never heard of all these talented Russian artists, we asked?
The displays and descriptions, helpfully translated into English, were excellent and we were impressed by the quality of the work.

Preferred to the Hermitage. A much more rewarding experience than trying to fight through the football crowds at the Hermitage. Very large and diverse exhibit, focusing more on art and related items than on building architecture. Provides an excellent overview of the history of Russian art, imagination and creativity, from the earliest iconography through to the 20th century. Very nice display of Vrubel's work, if you already been introduced to him at the Tretyakov. I would choose this over the Hermitage anyday.

One of the best in Russia. The Russian museum has a special, very calm and peaceful atmosphere. The museum has a vast collection of premium Russian painters, which is an absolute must, you've got to see and admire that.

Last Stop--Glad we made it. We'd had a week of seeing the glories of St Petersburg and were not at our best. Verging on exhausted and a bit glazed. But we were so very glad we made the effort to see the Russian Museum. Though we couldn't make it through the many rooms and exhibitions, we saw enough to gain a much finer appreciation of the country, the people, their history, pain, and glory, all expressed through art by artists we'd never heard of. The thematic and Scriptural parallels with great Renaissance artists and sculpture meant that many works felt familiar and were as moving as pieces we'd seen at the Hermitage. We're not proud that we knew so little of Russian art and artists prior to this visit.

Great collection of Russian artist!. Once again, it is a HUGE museum...The collection is very large and valuable, usually unknown to foreign tourists. The entire building has one spot for toilettes...
Non accompanied visit. Interesting exhibit but more relevance to the history of Russian art and culture rather than uniformly high quality of the works
A truly great Russian art gallery!. Don't skip this museum is you are an art lover. The collection is hand picked and of a manageable size. You'll never see russian art like this out side of Russia!

Wonderful Museum.. I really like this Museum, and prefer it to the too-vast Hermitage. Apart from the art, the interior architecture is wonderful. How I would have liked to be an aristocrat! I amazed one curator by pointing out my copy of a Polenov - Moscovskiy Dvorik - was different to theirs. She explained he painted several slightly different versions. Go find it!
Interesting for art lovers. It was interesting at first, hoewever, since the inner architecture is not as astonishing as the hermitage it got hard to look at all of these paintings.

Excellent Presentation. The State Russian Museum is extremely well presented in the Russian ethnic and diverse multicultural societies. The pride of the great mix by referring to their lifestyle and habitats give the visitors a very educational experience. Much of the museum can be easily covered with 2-3 hours without being bored. The presentation was done in such that visitors of different ages can enjoy without much reading the explanation. The plan of the museum gave the idea of seeing floor-by-floor however the place can only be visited wing-by-wing.

Amazing. Amazing museum. However, it was a bit chaotic.
We discovered great artists we never knew before.
A must.
PS. Eating at the cafeteria was nice and unexpensive.

No crowds here. As far as it comes to culture (and not to "must see"), the global mass group tourism has no interest. Fine! You can spend hours in this museum, and among others you can really enjoy the works of Repin.
not the first thing to do. Nice museum but should not be among the very first things to do on your list in my opinion. The collection is a bit thrown together.

A place to perceive the Russian art and culture. The museum is really interesting. I think it's one of those not numerous galleries where you actually meet the Russian art and culture, where you can observe the masterpieces of all times. Highly recommend

Better than the Hermitage IMHO. Nothing short of excellent. It was my impression that here you get really interesting first-rate Russian art. The amount is manageable in one day or two half days, without the long queues and hordes of selfie-posing tourists that clog the Hermitage.
Also recommended: the larger of the two cafés inside.

Fascinating collection of Russian art. This museum is really worth visiting and much less crowded than The Hermitage! It is fascinating to see how much Russian artists were influenced by what was happening elsewhere in the world for the first two decades of the twentieth century and then how they developed, when those contacts were broken. The building itself - the Mikhailovsky Palace - is also interesting and the park outside is delightful.

Lovely Range of Russian Art. Works rarely if ever reproduced in the west, this will be a unique treat for must, of beautiful portraiture (Russian painters have a knack for capturing the personality, the essence of the subject), many grand 19th century works and a few more modern pieces, as well as a fantastic range of folk art, including a wonderful collection of spectacular Russian lacquer miniatures, on boxes and other pieces. Well worth the visit if you can fit it in with all the other gems to see in St Pete's!

Don't miss it.. It is the largest collection of Russian art, several times the size of Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow. Don't miss to see icons, Nikitin's potraits , Ratrelli's sculpture of Anna Ivannovna wit a little Arab, the art works from the second half of the 19th century (e.g Ilya Repin) and the Russian Avant-Garde. Since museum is not crowded you'll have enough time to carefully explore artifacts. For only 800 R (cca. 11 Eur) you can buy excellent guidebook (160 pages) with illustrations much better than photos you can shoot in museum.

Stunning icons, Malevich, Serov & Repin. It takes a bit of an effort not to get lost in a complex system of stairs, but it would still be worth it! Impressive Icon collection, and jumping from there to the late 19th century: some beautiful work of Repon and Serov. Not to forget Malevich... It is quiet a miracle that the line here is so short compared to the Hermitage.

Don't miss it! amazing... Less crowded and a bit less hunted by hungry tourists, this is surely the second best museum after Hermitage. I would recommend it even only for the wonderful palace into which it is located. You will understand a lot about russian art and culture. Plus, you'll have a more relaxing time cause is less crowded and definitely smaller than Hermitage.

A good alternative to the Hermitage. A very very good museum with works from very different times, ancient and contemporary and from different genres, sculpture, painting. Depicts very well the exquisite excellence of Russian art.

Russian art at its best. This museum has a wonderful collection of Russian fine and applied art as opposed to the art generally collected by museums. For those interested in Russia and its history it is a must see.
A hidden gem. This museum is a lot less crowded, a lot fewer non-Russian visitors - then hermitage and full of some very impressive Russian collections.

Russian Art!. If you want to see Russian Art, you come to the State Russian Museum located in the majestic white white-columned Mikhailovsky Palace and home to an extensive collection of Russian art from the 12th to the 20th centuries. This museum offers an impressive collection of 19th century works, which are housed on the second floor of the Mikhailovsky Palace which was built in 1925. This is another building designed by the Italian architect Carlo Rossi, whose work is evident across the city. In 1890, Tsar Nicholas II decided to purchase the palace for the purpose of becoming Russia’s first national gallery. It was opened to the public in 1898. The Russian Museum collection contains more than 400,000 exhibits. Over the past twenty years, the museum complex has grown to include the Stroganov Palace, St Michael's (Engineers) Castle and the Marble Palace. The complex also includes the Mikhailovsky Gardens, Engineering Gardens, Summer Garden (including the Summer Palace) and the House of Peter the Great. Admission Fee – limited wheelchair accessibility.
Worth seeing!. Great Russian art through the ages, I enjoyed Ilja Repin the most, you can have an English guide and no such crowds as in the Ermitage!

collection of rare masterpieces. Everey time i visit "nothern capital" i try to reach The Russian Museum or Hermitage - last time i succeded bothso, impressions - this part of history of russsian art and painting in particular was less familiar for me, so I really enjoyed discovering itThere are always various exebitions (amids the regular ones), so U might get really lucky and see some rear exibits

Not to be Missed. Virtually every visitor to St. Petersburg goes to the Winter Palace and Church of Spilled Blood, but the State Russian Museum should join this duo. Just a short distance from the latter site, the art collection here is very extensive, featuring Russian artists. You won't feel the oppressive crowds that you likely experience at the Winter Palace and can enjoy the art at your leisure. Most works at least have the title and artist identified in English with occasional longer explanations.
Exquisite altar of Russian art. A wow sort of place containing endless masterpieces less known in the West. Much lesser crowds compared to the Hermitage.

Collection great Russian painters. The museum not far from the Erimitage Museum. Located in the city center.You should viist if interested in Russian culture and history. Less crowded than the Erimitage museum.

An absolute highlight. The footfall here is comparatively light and there is plenty of time for the visitor to look at the truly magnificent setting as well as the art collection. And what art! A wonderful collection of icons; the developments in portraiture in the 18th century, the major movements of the 19th century. The latter included a wonderful collection of pictures by the Wanderers, with masterpieces by Ge, Repin and Brulov. If you want to get close to the Russian artistic soul come here. I could have stayed here all day (but alas had booked tickets elsewhere) and was sad to iss its more modern exhibits.
Museum. Just Brilliant - a definite must see. Give yourself a day, and try not to get too lost, note there are two entrances to the Palace.

First meeting with Russian art. As i grew up on westren art,i did not realised what a great treasures are waiting for us on the other side of the wall.The visit of the state Ruswsian museum is a must for every visitor and not only for art loverss.IGAL

Instead of the Hermitage. The Hermitage is supposed to be brilliant but with 400 rooms was too much for me to consider. This Museum was still very large but somewhere that you could take in over a couple of hours or so (depending on your interest in art). Here you will find more contemporary art than you will find at the Hermitage.
A nice museum . So much to be seen in this Russian museum. May it be a rainy or a sunny day, the visit is worth it. From past to present and beyond. Many interesting pieces of history.
Interesting and rich. Very interesting museum, exceeding over many buildings, incl. Ethnographical museum, Museum of modern art, Marble palace

Favorite of All St. Peterburg Museums. I am an avid museum go-er. I can't say anything bad about the Hermitage except if you are short on time, skip it and visit the Russian Museum! You can see European art in Western Europe, but no where else can you see the magnificence, significance and brilliance of the history of Russian (& then Soviet) art! Start with iconography and keep on going! Folk art, fine art, ceramics, lace all the way up to the present. Unfortunately the Soviet Realism is temporarily nomadic, but hopefully it'll come back soon. Plan on spending a full day (or get a 3-day pass) and get an audio guide if you can't afford to go with a tour guide! I highly recommend and will return every time I'm in the city! BTW- Vrubel is my personal favorite!

More enjoyable than the hermitage . You can not and should not compare this to the hermitage with its vast collection. But the place is smaller, manageable in few hours and is focused on Russian art...we went there on Monday ( it is open while most places are closed) and it was raining. It was an enjoyable time and the only problem is the lack of English descriptions which is a real problem in Russia in general. You see different kind of artist with different landscapes and interesting modern section. Few interesting statues. I like it and would spend there 2 hours easily enjoying the place.

Worth every minute of visit. Precious Russian folk to fine art. The late-XIX century collection is wonderful as well as that of the interwar period. A hall is dedicated to the great Vereshchagin and several halls to carved bone and textile crafts. Take the museum plan with you, you will need it! Be sure to visit both wings, it can be confusing once you're in.
Huge art museum.. Disabled access is very poor. Disabled lift to upper floors of the annex was not working during our visit.However, the museum does contain a huge collection of art across the ages.

No Ayvazovsky . Unfortunately Ayvazovsky pictures aren't there anymore. Museum without the most popular painter is not the same anymore.Anyway you can enjoy beautiful pictures of other Russian painters, e.g. Shishkin, Repin...

A pleasant afternoon. As we found out, St. Petersburg centre is not as vast is may appear on the tourist maps and, although the Russian Museum is a little way out if you head from Nevsky Prospeckt towards 'On The Spilled Blood' it isn't much of a walk and well worth it as, with just about everything in St. Petersburg, it is in a beautiful building. I would recommend a visit when you've ticked all your other boxes
must go again. there is never enough time to enjoy the museum. amazing sculptures that attracts for hours. like the place very much. strongly recommend
Poor. After the Hermitage, it is nothing to do here. As for me I was expecting to see different folk and historical exhibits. Unfortunately it is just a gallery of Russian paintings.

Fascinating art. Really enjoyed strolling around this museum looking at art by Russian Nationals. It wasn't all "great art" but it was very interesting and a rewarding experience. Also it was not awash with guided tours, although they are available if you want them.I enjoyed the folk art section too, particularly the textiles, but if you like textiles you need the Ethnographic museum next door!

Small crowds, big art!. The most memorable museum visit while in this city rich with museums. Focused on Russian artists, the museum offers a in-depth look at art through its history. Highly recommend visiting the State Russian Museum!
Mixed. There were,paintings for all tastes and sculptures some it was hard to others were the artist had a very good view on what the viewer would like to see.
Covers 700 years of Russian art. Has a huge range of Russian art on display ranging from medieval icons to Kandinsky all displayed within a palace. Nice way to spend a rainy day.
Russian Masters. All Russian artists - a great collection - if you like religious icons their collection is stunning!
Interessting. Less crowd than ermitage. Had to wait for 35 minutes. Be early to avoid long lines. Inside restaurant is not mandatory. Food and service ok. Ambiente not what you are looking for.

Russian.... Russian museum with mainly paintings, all from Russian artists. Very good impression of Russian painting and social life.Nice palace is housing the museum. Beware of queues. They can be very long and slow...
Loved it. A visit to this museum gives a good idea of Russian art through the centuries. We visited between 5 - 6pm, which allowed us only to see a fraction of the exhibits, but without any crowds.

Many famous paintings. In State Russian Museum you can see many famous paintings such as Repin's "Barge Haulers on the Volga". Unfortunately, quite many paintings have description only in Russian. This can be annoying if you are not an expert in arts. The museum is large and it is easy to get lost, if you don't take a map from the ticket office. There is a free locker where you can leave your bag.

A musem to see. Absolutely. A beautiful museum I visited the first night when I was in St. Petersburg.The museum is open until 21 and costs 450 rubles per person.They are works of many artists mainly Russians but also the Europeans. both paintings and sculptures.You can see a bust dedicated to Rastrelli, who designed many buildings in St. Petersburg, including the ermitage.One of the best museums I've seen, even if you have a lot of Hermitage's competition..It deserves to be seen.
A quick hour. We most enjoyed the modern art and crafts exhibit. This museum is large, but not as busy as the Hermitage and focuses on Russian art.
Love it more than Hermitage. Not so crowded, great art collection, audio guide is a must if you are not a part of a guided tour group.

Best Russian Fine Art .. Nothing for Free ,but Very cheap to get in Museum,Churches ,Etc ($ 5-7/each) .To see so much history ,art all in one place ,painting,drawing and Sculpture the best of the best in the last 1000 years ,simply amazing

Spans the centuries of Russian art. The State Russian Museum occupies the Mikhailovsky Palace plus two wings (Rossi and Benois). Because my husband really needed to have a wheelchair, it was a tad challenging to get around, but the staff were helpful. I scooted up on my own to see the medieval Russian art -- not icons, as I’d expected, but some beautiful paintings of religious subjects on wood panels. We also skipped the folk and the decorative and applied art collections. All of the paintings were by Russian artists, and they spanned the 18th through the 20th Centuries, giving us a sense of how they had influenced each other, what many of them had learned in Paris, and how individual artists like Repin had developed. (Like their Danish counterparts, 19th Century Russian artists liked to paint landscapes in Italy and other sunny places.) We found the Soviet Realism especially interesting and were disappointed that the museum didn’t include propaganda posters and was rather thin on the Russian avant garde.
very good. I recomend.. I really liked, there were different type of works. I would say, that maybe even better than State Hermitage Museum

Amazing Russian painters. Highly recommended if you wish to see art by Russian painters. Some pieces were huge but still so crisp and painted at such a high level, it was breathtaking. There was an upper part of the exhibition, showcasing a bit more careless and rough art style: not my thing. The museum is also way smaller than I expected, compared to the Hermitage. Nonetheless I am happy I got to see true Russian art while in St Petersburg.

Fabulous selection of Russian art. This is a tremendous selection of Russian art over many centuries, well hung in an impressive traditional building. Personnel are everywhere and can be very helpful for wayfinding.

Plan ahead to get most out. Great cafe, good value food freshly made. Very helpful staff. The 20th art work was worth seeing, enjoyed seeing Russian art work and folk crafts, discount for uk students,

The Russian Museum - A Window on Rudsian Culture. The Russian Museum is a very interesting museum located in the vicinity of the Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood.What makes this museum particularly interesting is the fact that its collection features only Russian made objects. These amazing works of art range from humble folk art to imperious portraiture. This museum is an ideal companion to the Hermitage, as both museums together give a better picture of the Russian spirit.

Amazingly good and surprisingly broad collection.. Our visit to the Russian Museum was very informative. I must admit that we are not very familiar with most of the Russian painters (except the modern ones like Kandinsky, Malewitch etc.). So most of the paintings were new to us. And of course we did not like them all, but I am glad we went there and spent some time. Important to us was also the fact that there were not so many visitors (compared to for instance the Hermitage) so we could quietly walk around and look in more detail at the things that looked interesting.

Large Art Museum. This is the largest art museum in St. Petersburg after The Hermitage. While each art museum tends to be unique and specialize in a particular style. If you like the style of art they house, then you must go!

Great museum of rich russian heritage concerning the art, design and history !. That is the site we wanted to see beside the great Hermitage Museum, since as in Moscow, we looked for something genuine russian in its provenance. And such edifice of wonderful russian art we found within the State Russian Museum. It is located in Inzhenernaya Street that is accessible from the Metro Station Gostiny Dvor in Nevsky Prospekt.The Museum has a nice location, with view at the Church of Savior on Spilled Blood, the Monument to A.S. Pushkin in front of the building,the beautiful Mikhailovsky Garden behind.Again, after the Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow we met with the great russian artists, painters. Here they are, Nikitin, Brullov, Aivazovsky ( great marin painter), then magic Ilya Repin, Victor Vasnetsov, Vasily Surikov, Valentin Serov, Boris Kustodiev and Kasimir Malevich.As to the building of the Museum, so called Mikhailovsky Palace, it has done in Neoclassical architectural design.Great pleasure for us was our visit to this splendid Museum.

Wonderful Art and Design. This is a spectacular museum. It is a maze of history, artifacts and art, with something for everyone. I particularly liked the folk art and textiles, which offered a clear insight into Russian cultures of dress and display. The artworks were great, offering a broad overview of art history, with some contemporary pieces too. You need a good 4 hours to race through, so do take your time.

Savor Russian artists who are less well known outside of Russia. The highlight was the very broad range of output of Russian artists, the great majority of them unknown to normal Americans like myself. For virtually every esthetic movement in Western painting in the 19th and 20th century – 19th-century everyday realism, pastoralism, impressionism, expressionism, cubism, and more – there were skilled Russian practitioners working in the same movement, and possibly others as well. Of course, the paintings also contain many references to Russian historical and cultural themes, a few of which I was able to appreciate, and the majority of which I didn’t know enough to recognize.A few other comments on the museum visit. First, we only visited the main building – Mikhailovsky Palace. The building is impressive from the outside, but much more modest on the inside, at least when compared with the Winter Palace/Hermitage interiors we’d visited the day before. It’s less spectacular, but this also can be a good thing, because the artwork doesn’t have to compete with the walls, floors, ceilings, and decorations as much. It was busy, but nowhere near as crowded as the Hermitage, or other most-popular sights in St. Petersburg, particularly with fewer tour groups. The museum is laid out in such a way that if you want to follow an easy route to tour virtually all of the rooms in chronological order, you can do so, although you don’t have to do it this way. Finally, as a practical note, use the restrooms when you first come in – we saw bathrooms right near both the main entrance and the Benois Wing entrance – because we didn’t see ones available elsewhere in the museum.

you have to see ilja Repin pictures. take the audio guide and just tell yourself that you only would like to see a part.. do not rush and for that part take your time..stick to your promise, otherwise you get the feeling you missed out so much.. better than erimitage

Brilliant museum/art gallery.. This is a very do-able gallery with a wide range of Russian art through the ages and folk art. I had been hoping to see some art from 20th century and was delighted to find some here. Good toilets too.
Excellent addition to Hermitage visit. It has many great painting by Russian artist. To me it was especial since I saw many works previously on my textbooks. it also has a great view of old Russia.

Beautiful collection of Russian art. It is an impressive collection of Russian art through the ages. The buildings need a face-lift, but impressed by the breadth of the collection. The café staff were very pleasant, but the menu is limited and the space is dingy.
Much better than the Hermitage. An incredible collection, well displayed and laid out - only let downs were the very rude staff and the old-fashioned, dingy cafe.
Impressive Collection. If you go there, take the rest of the day off. It's so big, you will a have a hard time to fully get in one shot. One of the biggest collections there is.

another huge museum! Just Russian art. Well worth a walk through if you have a few days in St. Petersburg, and a quick spin - not stopping much - would take about an hour. Right next to the excellent ethnographic museum, so the two of them make a great way to spend a couple hours. 10 mins walk from Faberge.

Excellent in all ways. The museum has everything you could want to see. It is all kept in exquisite shape. Clean and beautiful. It is definitely a strong representation of all that was and is wrong with government. The museum is amazing.
Ms.. This is a wonderful museum of artworks by of very talented Russian artists. All genres of art are represented. I highly recommend it.

Wow! Authenic images of landscapes and events before photos. My favorite museum in St. Petersburg. They have an excellent collection of iconography and Russian Orthodox church items. However the enormous collections of art work depicting villages, battle scenes, political events and landscapes give you the history and beauty of Russia from centuries long ago.

My favourite in St.Petersbourg. If you want to know more about the russian art and to see the best russian artists - you must go the the Russia State Museum. It is huge and the collection is very rich from the ancient russian art to the modernt art such as Kandinsky and Malevitch.

Great museum . Been there a few times, very beautiful museum, a must see in Saint Petersburg, located at the center of the city, 5 minutes walking from Nevsky street. it is allowed to go in with stroller (not an often thing in Russian museums)

Brilliant collection. The museum collection can be compared of that in Tretyakov Art Gallery in Moscow. The works of art are incredible, many of them are well-known not only to Russian people but abroad. Don`t miss it if you appreciate pictorial art.

Must-see museum, could use a few small improvements.. This is a must-see museum if you enjoy classical art. The major focus of the museum is on art of Russian artists from the 17th to the 20th centuries (mainly 18th and 19th century). There are some other exhibits as well, such as Russian folk art and Circus Arts exhibits. The museum consists of the main building and the Benoit building to which it is connected. You start out by going up the magnificent stairs to the second floor and then viewing the rooms in a counter clockwise direction. After that down to the first floor and rooms 18-35, and proceed to the Benoit building. Some featured artists are Shishkin, Repin, Serov, Kandinsky, Malevich and many others. I would give 5 stars for the collection, and 3 or even 2.5 for overall museum environment. Some reasons for the low rating of the environment. The labeling on many of the paintings is in really tiny print, and very difficult to read until you walk right up to it, even with my 20/20 vision. A significant number of the paintings are missing the year they were painted. Some translations and spelling into English are wrong or misspelled. When I first started viewing on the second floor all of the rooms were unbearably hot, even with me just wearing a tee-shirt. On top of being extremely annoying for the visitors, this cannot be good for the paintings, especially those that do not have glass protection of which there are many. Other rooms later on had open windows, which was great was the cool breeze, but again, I imagine this cannot be good for those paintings that are unprotected by glass. It also appears that the curators have not yet mastered the art of lighting displays and idea of non-reflective glass. It is virtually useless to take pictures of many of the paintings due to the really strong reflection of the the light. These were just some of my pet peeves, but do not let them stop you from visiting. Again, the collection deserves 5 stars on its own. Also, a guide might be a worthwhile idea, although I did the whole museum by myself in 3 hours and saw virtually everything.
Must see the gold Peacock Clock. Can't possibly get round everything, boiling hot day, but no liquids allowed, till you get to the Café.

Don't pay for expensive tours you Can do it yourself. State museum has lots of artBuy the 600 ruble pass to see 5 sites in one passLots of little gift shops everywhere in the museumHave cashYou can do these tours by yourself you can walk everywhereI enjoyed the decorative artsI spent 2 hours

Marvellous Russian Art. This Museum only contains Russian art which was removed from The Winter Palace. It was quite a revelation to us, as we had never really seen any before. Really marvellous works of art and I am only sorry, we did not have longer to really look at everything, as we had for the Airport. Charming staff too.

Comprehensive collection of Russian paintings over the years. For anyone unfamiliar with Russian paintings over the year, from icons - which are fascinating - onwards this might be demanding. It is very big indeed but there are some very good works

It's a nice musea to have a visit. If you like musea buy the allround ticket for 650 rubles and you can visit 6 musea's who work together. It was interesting musea to visit, not extreme big, 3 hours spending.

Grumpy staff. Worth a visit but make sure you are not there anywhere near closing time. Museum closes at 6 but by 5.30 pm staff are tutting and constantly checking watches as you go from room to room, shops were all locked up by 5.45 as well, unwelcoming which is a shame as a treasure trove of Russian art here.

Great art. Brilliant selection of Russian art in a more manageable quantity than other museums. Great explanations and well displayed, beautiful Malevich et al, near the Spilled Blood so can be combined with both finish at Jamies Italian for a totally inauthentic end!

Incredibly large selection of top Russion paintings. Russian painters are not so well known in Europe, but they painted gigantic pictures of battles and scenes of early Russia and it's emperors. I am often visiting art museums, but I have seldom seen such beautiful paintings of Russian artists (such as their most famous painter: I. J. Repin). If you love Rembrandt and Rubens, you will love Repin. This is an art museum which is not such known to Europeans, but for the Russians an absolute MUST. I would recommend to visit it, but you should have at least some 4 hours time available.

Surprisingly not so huge as Hermitage and with perfectly arranged collection. It is located in a great palace, specially built to house an art muzeum. So after a rather tricky ground floor, which is really a labirinth where you will search for a yours cloakroom and toilets and also exits to the street or to the exposition, you will walk to a perfectly arranged collection. It is not as large as it looks, so 1 day is really enough to visit it and calmly observe the main exposition + maybe another day for the temporary excibitions. It is not inhumanly huge, complex and overcrowded like the Hermitage. Its collection is housed in rather small rooms, each of which precisely reflects steps in the history of Russian art with rather small number of paintings per each, but houses some of the most famous masterpieces of Russian artists. It`s for quality, not quantity.

Do your homework before visting. To get the best out of the Russian museum you need to do your research before you go. The place is enormous and has temporary as well as permanent exhibits - we made the mistake of just turning up and going round a large modern art exhibition which isn't my thing at all.I'd love to go back and do some research before visiting as I'm sure we missed loads but just ran out of time. Nice restaurant / café though.As with all Russian museums, check opening days and times - they often have all day and half day closing even in the height of the tourist season.
What a place!. As with all the museums, galleries etc in StP there is so much to see that a half day visit did not do this justice! An art collection you won't see anywhere else in the world.

Very helpful staff, great art. We only visited the Benois Wing:Not the palatial experience of the Hermitage, but very enjoyable as an art museum. Loved the Kandinsky, Finolov, and others. Loved the two Roerich's lining the staircase.

wonderful collection. we wandered past the Saviour of the blood church through the park and around the back to the museum. A lovely walk and a nice contrast between nature and the collection of art inside the museum. The museum is a bit more manageable that the hermitage so you don't end up getting hot and bothered and bog-eyed by the sheer vastness of the art on view. Some amazing art on display.
A must see. Fantastic museum which we hadn't intended to go to but so glad we did. Amazing paintings - we spent a good couple of hours in here.

Grand Art of Russia!. The State Russian Museum is the mecca of Russian Art. Take at least a day to explore the huge collection. If you are on a cultural journey through Russia, a visit here is really a must to begin piecing together the country's vast and complicated history.

History of Art. From iconic painting to modern Russian art, this is a must-visit attraction for art lovers. This could well be at least a half-day visit and ideally during the off tourist season so you are under no pressure to move on too fast inside.

invaluable art heritage. Great museum with invaluable art collection! Quite a lot of time is needed just to look it through and I think one day won't be enough to look over all exhibits.There are permanent and also temporary exhibitions. The staff is very friendly and will do all the best to help u and provide explanations if requested. Quite a lot of tiny shops on different floors for souvenir hunters. Audio guides are provided for extra charge. Very useful option for those who has time - 3-days complex ticket which is valid in all Russian Museum buildings.

For everyone who loves Russian painters. State Hermitage is amazing museum but Russian Museum is the right place for those who want to discover Russian artists (mainly painters). I have never been to Tretyakov Gallery so this was my first "real" encounter with Savrasov, Levitan, Aivazovsky, Shiskin, Kuindzi, Polenov, Repin and other great artists.

Great Russian paintings here. I initially wasn't too interested in coming here but am glad I did. The artworks are quite impressive in a range of styles. It is largely paintings and ranges from portraits to landscape and religious.
Great art museum. It only costs 400 ruble to go in and it has a very good modern Russian art section ( all I had time to see).

Had expected more of it. I thought the Russian museum was one of the least impressive museums to visit in St Petersburg: mostly just sculptures and paintings (and a lot of paintings were from Russian painters painting in Italy or other European countries), but very few iconic paintings from the Orthodox church, virtually no communist art, no Russian photography... If you like Russian artists copying Western artists, you are at the right address, but we had hoped to see more variation.

The red-headed Wednesdays stepchild of the Hermitage but superb.. This is like the Hermitage "Lite". I highly recommend because there's a whole lot less people, tons and tons of wonderful Russian art which most people don't know anything about, even though they should and it's much smaller and can be done in 2 hours if you so desire.

Fairylike Russian Museum. Slowly walking and there is an wonderfull world coming to you: Beautiful paintings,furniture,statues..every room is a surprise,I do not what is nr1: the Hermitage or the Russian Museum
Russian Art Museum is unique. Museum offers collection of Russian Art from icons to modern art, self-guided tours are available in many languages

Great museum of Russian art. Went in not knowing much about Russian art and discovered some amazing artists that should probably be better known. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys great paintings or even to see some images of Russian history.

Beautiful. The main building of the museum is the Mikhailovsky Palace, a splendid Neoclassical residence of Grand Duke Michael Pavlovich, erected in 1819-25. Just a wonderful palace to host a wonderful collection of Russian art. The museum is rather informative and it clearly points out the development of Russian Art. If you are coming to Saint Petersburg this place is a must see.

Excellent and informative museum. I went round this museum with my daughter who is studying Russian at University and she thought it represented Russian history and culture very well. We think this should be a key visit on a visitor's itinerary.

Best Musuem to see Russian art. I visited this museum multiple times while studying in Russia. The critical artwork collection is amazing, and I consider it to be a MUST-SEE if you're visiting Petersburg.

Not to be missed!. This was a great afternoon of art. From icons to modern, the art was excellent. I rented the audio guide and that was really interesting. Plan on about 4 hours to see all the areas of this museum. I loved it.

A superb and comprehensive collection of Russias golden period. A collection covering the Academic stile to the to Russian impressionists and expresionists all together in a beautifull palace close to the Hermitage and other landmark sights in the center. If you want a focussed collection go there if you are tired of the Hermitage.
Worth it. I absolutely recommend this museum. Its collection ist just amazing! More than that - the building inside is another piece of art!
Art place. Love art? It is defiantly your cup of tea Visit, enjoy, learn, and tell everyone to come and see It will not disappoint art lovers
Must be seen. It is an essential to see if you are in the city. But if you like only painting. Otherwise I see it is boring.
Fantastic museum. You should not skip it. It is one of greatest museums of Russian art. Do not forget to enjoy paintings of Ivan Aivazovsky.
History galore!. Great for the whole family or solo travellers. I went and walked around the museum which is in variuous buildings, quite a good walk. Spend at least 2 hours here if you have time.

Russian Museum-the national art collection.. Russian Museum-the national art collection.Beautiful Palace created by Carlo Rossi in the 19th century holds a collection of paintings by Russian artists,together with the Tretyakov gallery and the Pushkin Museum in Moscow,will be the full experience and enjoyment by Russian masters of the brush!

Must see. This is a "must-see" if you are in St. Petersburg - on of the most prominent art collections in Russia. I admit there are some flaws (mentioned by other tripadvisor members and rather typical for all Russian museums) - imperfect lighting, not very pleasant toilets, queue at the wardrobe). But they are 100% outweighted by the unique collection of Russian paintings and sculptures.

Wonderful Museum but best to schedule an excursion. Very cool museum. Good descriptions of the works in English to help, but I would suggest having a tour guide for 2 reasons. First, they are licensed and can give you a much more fulfilling experience. Secondly, they can get you into the museum without a wait, which can sometimes last for a couple hours.My favorite displays are the 6 ton bronze of Catherine the Great, the Russian folk art, and the Knight at the Crossroads.Wear comfortable shoes and plan on a few hours (inside) to get the most out of your visit.

Nice museum with a vast collection of Russian art. A nice museum with a vast collection of art. Good to visit this museum before you visit the Hermitage as the hermitage is so overwhelming. Worth to spend an afternoon here.

Good alternative to the busy Hermitage. The Russian museum is a mandatory stop each time I visit St. Petersburg. In contrast to the Hermitage, it is usually quiet, allowing for a casual stroll along my favourite works of art. Queues at the entrance are rare, and it allows exploring the various exhibits ay my own pace. The Benois wing features an impressive collection of modern Russian art in its permanent collection, as well as interesting temporary exhibits. It can be a bit hard to find, so be sure to get a map when entering the museum. It is by far my favourite museum in St. Petersburg.

One of my favorite museums !. I was born and growing up in St.Petersburg and finally after more than 20 years I visited Russian Museum again...I definitely was not disappointed: everything looked the same. I again admired the historical building and great collection of art.Please, try to spend the business day in the Russian museum: from 10 am to 6 pm. It's enough time to observe everything.You could have a lunch in the museum's cafe, but remember: credit cards are not accepted there ( though you could use it to buy tickets). I recommend to get the audio guide. And don't miss Ivan Aivazovsky's collection!
A true gem. When we visited at Christmas we seem to be almost the only Non-Russian visitors. Wee laid out, and if you don't know Russian art you will be overwhelmed by the vast mix of subjects.

Beautiful park and amazing exhibits. The museum had a park outside of the building itself and the staff working there were very friendly. They were willing to show and guide us inside the building. Enjoyed the art exhibits the most and the QR code was definitely helpful as an alternative to having a guide for the tour.

Beautiful building and collection!. Have to say I like the looking of the museum more than the collections inside... Maybe because I did Hermitage first so Russian museum cannot easily impress me after that... Inside was a bit dated to be honest, but the collections are amazing - mainly Russian painting and art pieces - great venue to learn about Russian art of different time period!

Don't miss the folk. A Russian friend and museum aficionado shared that the babushkas staffing each room are one of the real stressors of his museum experience. They can be possessive, grumpy sometimes even downright hostile. If it helps, remember They're also horribly underpaid. For me they add to the Russian ness of the whole thing. Nowhere more true than at the Russian museum. I was taking pictures of my favorite wooden miniatures of a posse of mice parading a bound cat and was on the receiving end first of one of the fiercest scowls I've ever witnessed, then, once I'd noticed the eyes boring into the back of my head - a heated and clearly disapproving lecture in Russian, with arm waving. Saw others, Russians, also snapping pics with impunity so I'm still not sure what was going on. Anyway, this museum has some extraordinary holdings, including great grim and charming Russian folk art. Definitely go.

wonderful. I spent all day but it was not enough,one of the reason I vent this museum to see ivan ayvazovski ,and many more famous painter such van gogh,I definetly recomend and I will definetly visit again

Russian Art in Its Best. It originally was New Michael Palace designed by Rossi and built by Alexander I for his younger brother.If you like Russian Icons, and Russian art of the 18-20th centuries, it is the place to visit.Plan at least 3-4 hours .If you do not have much time you can see a small section of the museum based in Benua building. There are usually temporary exhibitions there.
Worth spending the whole afternoon. So many interesting local pieces! I am not an art person but the works there still impress me and hold me for the whole afternoon.
Great museum. One another must...Classical, modern art...Make sure you have one whole day...If there is a big line from the main door, go around and get inside from the Griboedov channel door.
Only for real art lovers. This is the only museum which I suggest to visit only for a real deep art lover. This museum is dedicated only to Russian art and only to paintings.

Educational introduction to Russian Artists. If icons are your thing - it is wonderful to see such ancient works from 13th and 14th Centuries. I liked the portraiture and the landscapes by artists I had not previously heard of - wonderful work. Our guide's husband gave us excellent insight into the history of Russian art.

So easy to just drop in to and enjoy. After joining a Russians only Boat Cruise that allowed us just take pictures we found just enough time to do a quick walk through this amazing collection. The Taster as after 2 hours that was all it could be has us wanting to return for more

Wonderful museum of Russian art. This museum is definitely worth a visit! So much fabulous art which I was appalled to discover I knew nothing about!! All is displayed beautifully in splendid palatial rooms. Russian museums require you to leave your coat and bags in a cloakroom and special mention must be made of the ladies who work so hard there!! No restrictions on cameras and photography. I thought the museums icon collection was marvellous.

Large, rich, and quite beautiful. While everyone goes to the Hermitage — perhaps even more than once —, it seems that few people come to the Russian Museum, which is a shame.The collection is quite rich, the rooms beautiful, and the visit very pleasant, as I sometimes had a room to myself! You will see objects from every period of Russian civilization, up to the very modern stuff. The only thing missing, in my opinion, was "Socialist Realism" and Soviet art, which there were very few examples of.Enjoy your visit!

Nothing special- not recommended for tourists. There are of course a handful of famous/beautiful works of art here but most of the artists are not well known outside Russia. Not worth the amount of time to walk through the whole thing. You would be better off spending more time at the Hermitage. The park behind the palace is beautiful.

Worth a return visit!. My husband & I were taken to the Russian Museum by our private guide & were so engaged by it, that we returned on our own for a full day. It was a real learning about Russian (only) art & the whole Russian culture - a very different experience than the collections of international art which tend to get more attention. Great English audio-guide enhanced our time & it was a pleasant walk from our Helvetia Hotel.

Nice place to visit. As opposed to the Hermitage, this place is full of Russian works. Most of them are unknown to us but they were well done. This is another place in St. P that should not be missed.

One of the greatest museums. I have always liked the Russian Museum featuring many great Russian artists. Unfortunately, my last visit was spoiled by an unbelievable rudeness of the staff in the halls.

Go for the art not the architecture.. We hired a private guide to see some places "off the beaten path" of the usual tours in St Petersburg and were so happy we did. Our guide was amazing. She knew every picture, artist and style of painting in the museum. While the Hermitage is on every standard tour, it has European art, and we wanted to see Russian art. It is in a palace, just not one of the more spectacular ones. But we were so glad we chose the Russian Museum. Really enjoyed the experience. Not sure how it would have been without the guide though.
Russian Museum. A great museum full of incredible Russian paintings. Each room made your eyes even wider and wider. Well worth a visit.

A really nice museum. Like I always say, I'm not really a museum person, but the museums in SPB impressed me. This museum is not quite as stunning as the Hermitage, but definitely worth seeing, as it has cool art of its own and also has memorable walls/ceilings.

More Russian art than you thought you'd ever see. Largest collection of Russian art; displayed in magnificent palace. Collections well organized. I read up on the museum before going because I didn't remember or know many artists. Was unable to take a tour. Easier on the eyes and feet than the Hermitage.

Do not miss this art palace - it can rival any art gallery in the world. Very big if not bigger than the famous Tretyakov Gallery (also only housing Russian artist works). It's a confusing to me which is which since I went into two separate buildings with separate admission ticket. The first building I went in is probably The Stroganov Palace, built on the corner of Nevsky Prospekt . Since I didn't see some of the famous paintings I was expecting to see, I asked where they are. Then I was directed to The Mikhailovsky Palace, which is the main building. Yes, you need to buy a separate ticket here but it's so worth it. There are noticeably some of the same paintings you would see in Tretyakov Gallery and I don't understand why. I'm still digging into the information. BTW-there's very limited English translation anywhere in Russia. I usually purchase the museum guide book (catalogue) for me to read during and after my visit. This is a grand museum with beautiful palaces. Those paintings are memorable and you can only experience by seeing the color, the large scale and the striking depiction in person.
Enjoy!. This is a huge building. I was impressed by how well-maintained this and other Russian attractions are kept.

Perfect day off from Hermitage. We visited the museum on Monday (the day the Hermitage is closed) and we're glad we did. Unlike the Hermitage it ONLY features Russian artists and exhibited a wonderful display from early iconography through to 20 century/ modernist masters. It is not as "well loved" on the inside (some chipped/ mismatched paint) but the main interiors and salons are spacious and well lit. It also houses two beautiful and MASSIVE works from Ivan Aivazovsky. A Russian master who did stunning seascapes -- (actually he painted over 6000 pieces). It also holds a very impressive Last Day of Pompeii and Bruni's The Brazen Serpent (which is the largest canvas in their collection). There are also smaller table sized showcases (covered with velvet flaps) around the edges of the largest rooms. It's a little confusing but visitors are welcome to lift these little flaps and view beautiful little pen and ink, oil and watercolor drawings hidden beneath them (to prevent them from fading) The only thing I didn't like was the museum itself was a little disjointed/ maze like as it is comprised of 2 separate buildings. I also thought the rented audio guide was good-- but wished more artworks were covered by it.
Russian paintings. a place to go if you like Russian painters, a huge collection of paintings there, including Vrubel...
Magnificent. The 19th Century Russian painters are superb and this Museum accounts for that. It also houses an interesting exhibition of the 20th Century Russian art. A must visit.

Don't miss this!. We toured this museum on our own, following the advice of hotel staff who recommended it for its Russian art. (Understand that the Hermitage is full of European art.) Decent audio guide, although I would have liked more pieces to have been included. Glad I chose this over seeing yet another palace. In this case, art definitely reflects culture. Even if we weren't thrilled to see this art, seeing the babuschki guarding each and every room was art unto itself.

Russian Museum. We were in St Petersburg long enough that we could see some of the Museums not on the must see lists! We were the only people wandering through when we arrived at opening time. The cost is modest, the art quite lovely though not on par with the Hermitage, it is relaxing to walk through the galleries and not feel crushed by crowds as is the case at the Hermitage. It is a collection of art by Russian artists, many who were influenced by French and other European artists.

Well worth the visit. While the contents are not as "glamorous" or "famous" as in the Hermitage (no Rembrandts or Rubens) it is, nonetheless, very much worth visiting. An incredible array of paintings, folk crafts, ceramics, glass and porcelain. A couple of Kandinsky and Malevich paintings, too, but they should not be the reason for your visit. All the other stuff is much more interesting.
Well worth a visit.... Great afternoon spent in here, was a bit complex to work out where to go and not get lost but I got there by asking the friendly staff.

Worth a visit even after seeing the Hermitage. The museum is in an impressive palace building. The collection is interesting. The sheer size of some of the pieces make it worth seeing. You need at least and hour and a half to two hours to visit. I would do it on a day other than when you visit the Hermitage. It is conveniently located off Nevsky Pr.

Russian paintings by Russian painters. Marvelous paintings of Russian life and landscapes. It is a door to the vastness of Russia and it's mysterious soul!We spent a half a day being enchanted. You truly appreciate the Russian genius.

Russian Art, Excellent Visit. This has been a museum since 1895, so I'd say they have some experience in showcasing art and handling visitors. Nicholas II offered this former palace as well as an enormous personal collection for the public and it has grown since then. Magnificent collection of Russian art. The gallery of Icons was a wonderful way to start. Wonderful selection of paintings, and the sculptures - Vitali's Venus! exquisite. I would be happy to revisit on my next trip.Recommended.The museum is closed on Tuesdays, and opens at 1300 on Thursdays. There are heaps of food choices within a short walk, including Italian and Indian food. We went for a well-deserved lunch before walking to our next stop.

Former palace, museum now. This museum is in the city center. It is located in a former palace. Again, this building is nice also form the outside. The inside is may be even nicer to see. They have a lot of Russian art, paintings, ceramics, furniture, statues, …… One should have seen this. Be careful, on Thursday open only from 13:00 hours onwards.

Excellent collection of Russian art!. The collection is huge, so It's really recommended to everybody who is fond of Russian art! The best way to discover it is to take an audio guide or with a private guide cause there's so much history behind it. This museum is not in the top of the things to do in St Petersburg, it's more for interested people, but it's really amazing!

russian art in all its ways. when visiting petersburg one wants to see the highlights such as hermitage, pushkin and peterhof, of course. but there is so much more to explore in and around this magnificent city.the russian museum is one good example. in the main building of it, which is the mikhailovsky palace, they offer a vast collection of russian art in every way and every style. that was very interesting. I wonder why not more of those are better known around the globe. there is tsaristic art, too, and other items of imperial times. the other branches of the russian museum are splendid as well: stroganov palace, marble palace, mikhailovsky castle,...

The Russian Museum has a rich collection. The Russian Museum has a rich collection of icons, paintings and sculptures by Russian artists from the 14th to the 21st century. I know and love the main collection therefore often I visit the temporary exhibitions held in the Benois Wing branch of the museum.The last exhibition I saw was an exhibition of paintings by artists of the 30s of the 20th century.The Russian Museum is the former Palace of Grand Duke Mikhail therefore the museum is surrounded by a very picturesque Mikhailovsky Garden.

Complete and amazing collection. It has something for everybody. Old and new. Classic and contemporary. Barroque and modern. From paintings, to sculptures and home utensils. Its a great journey through Russian art. I've spend 4 hours in the museum, I've really took my time to enjoy this trip and it was totally worth it.

Superb Collection!. This museum holds a breathtaking collection of Russian art well arranged and exhibited. (For artists from other countries, visit the Hermitage.) Beginning with medieval church iconography and royal portraits one can observe the development of art and the wonderful expansion of artists' subjects and styles. I was thrilled to see two rooms filled with stunning works by Repin. I had limited time and had to leave after viewing some of the late 19th Century, early 20th Century art, so I didn't get to see any of the new additions such as the sculpture or folk art collections, or the Marble or Stroganov Palaces. This collection and the Hermitage will probably draw me back for an extended visit to the city. Audio tours are available, but I didn't get one because I didn't have much time (90 minutes) and wanted to see as much as possible.

Enlightening and beautifully curated collection. Not only does St Petersburg, as the cultural center of the country, have a large and diverse number of museums to visit, but they are all very affordable when compared to many other famous European museums. When I entered the state art museum, I'll admit that I had very little knowledge of the country's contributions. I exited the museum with a broadened understanding of and appreciation for their rich history. Some of the most striking paintings I've ever seen were ones I found here. Highly, highly recommended. Don't miss this museum.
If you love Russian art. It is not as impressive as Hermitage as it is only a gallery, but if you want to see Russian paintings this is the best place to see them.

Skip the Hermitage. Save it for later. Start here, instead. Admission is 350 RUB - about 6 USD. And there are never any lines.I mean, why stand in line to see a few relatively minor paintings by the old Italian & Dutch masters, when you could instead see Ilya Repin's "Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks" and so much else that is really, really *Russian* for next to nothing?

Best Museum of Russian Art. Gives the history of Russia in art--fabulous collection of Russian art. Walk through the history of Russia through its famous art---beginning with historical icons from early Russia and Kiev andante the portraits of famous early Russians, fabulous art of historical events, interesting collection of Russian Impressionists- the Wanderers, art describing Russian stories and myths, night art, and contemporary Russian art---showing the impact of the revolution on art. Also an interesting exhibit of art during World War II--The Great Patriotic War.

Come here to see fantastic Russian art!. If you are interested in Russian art from early icons to the 20th century, come here rather than the Hermitage! It is not crowded even in August and there is so much to see, including the buildings themselves. We had a private guide but the shop sells a very good Guidebook which helps you to learn about these artists who are relatively unknown to us in the UK. This was the top attraction for us, along with the Peterhof gardens.

Nice historical reference for the city. While the Heritage is often the focus of most visits to the city, if you have the time, don't skip this museum. We found that this offered a more historical reference point for the city and housed only Russian art and works. This was a nice change.

Sublime Russian art. Love this museum of all Russian art and craft. The exhibition to commemorate WW2 and the Siege of Leningrad moved me to tears- very raw powerful works. The earlier classical art is gorgeous and it was marvellous to see painters' works for the first time. The decorative arts collection is extensive and very well displayed with a history of their development. This was a highlight of my St Petersburg visit.

For Art lovers. This museum is good for people who want to see paintings fromdifferent centuries. and from some famous russian artists likeAivasovski, Repin, etc.Reserve min 2-3 hours to see the main halls.

As Interesting as the State Hermitage Museum. Spare a day for the Russian Museum in your plans. It was recommended by a Russian friend and both the building and its contents are superb. We were particularly impressed by the very large collection of Russian paintings, the majority by artists previously unknown to us, and of excellent quality and interest. They range from enormous canvases many metres in dimension, to fascinating portraits and scenes. There is an extensive collection by Shishkin and Repkin, including the latter's fascinating "Zaporozhye Cossacks Writing a Mocking Letter to the Turkish Sultan". The sculptures on display are equally interesting. As with the Hermitage, as the collection is within a palace with large windows, the lighting in a number of instances is far from ideal because reflections obscure parts of the picture wherever you stand. On the plus side, photography (but no flash) is permitted, enabling you to keep a comprehensive memento of your visit.

Most Fabulous Collection of Russian Art!. Spend at least 3 hours or more here. It has a wonderful collection of Russian fine arts. We discovered most beautiful works of art by artists until now, unknown to us. They have a nice little cafe for tea to rest your legs mid-visit. You can buy stamps there for a few postcards. It is a short walk from Nevsky Prospekt near Arts Square. A very special place and a must while in St Petersburg.
Best museum of Russian art. Great collection of Russian artists, particularly Russian avantgarde. Most probably, the best in the world. Do not miss!

A must see.. If you love art, this place is a must. There are more hugh paintings in this building than I have ever seen before. Also beautiful textiles, costumes and lace work. There's a nice park across the street where you can sit and relax at the end of the day.

Interesting History and Art. This museum only receives four stars because the competition in St Petersburg is so great! This museum in any other city would be the top sight seeing venue, but St Petersburg has so many other places to see. This museum is a great second or third day tour if you are visiting the city for a few days.
Excellent museum!. Has a nice collection of artefacts and drawings. This is besides the armoury collection. The gold leaves are real! =)
Delightful. The Russian Museum is simply amazing! Housing the works of Russian artists,I was delighted with the incredible artwork. And it was certainly less crowded than the Hermitage!

packed with treasures. one of our best visits in st. petersburg. the museum encompases thousands of artworks from old to modern eras if Russia. we had a giude with us who took us around and explained history behind each work. this place needs a minimum of a full day to absorb all. Great eye opening to Russian art.

Worth going to. This is a great place to check out if you're interested in Russian artists, and want to be in an environment that is far calmer and less crowded than the Hermitage. The museum is pretty easy to navigate after a few minutes of wandering around, and their collection includes a variety of different artists and different time eras
Very interesting collections. We found the visit more interesting than expected. The collection covers a lot of Russian art and history. I certainly recommend it.

Visit if you have too much free time. I'm an art lover but this museum is not that impressive. Just visit it if you have nothing else to do otherwise instead of going to this museum go for the second day visit to Hermitage Museum.

From Icons to contemporary art, only Russian Art. The Hermitage Museum houses the European art and the Russian Museum houses the Russian art. We've seen icons before, but we have very little exposure to Russian art otherwise. Ivan Aivazovsky's work, Russia's great sea/maritime painter, really intrigued me. There's a monumental painting of a ship going down in a storm that's worth a visit to the museum on its own. Note: The museum is in a former palace, but don't expect the beautiful excesses of the palace that houses the Hermitage museum!

Amazing Russia. If you want to learn about Russian fine arts, visit this place with its most excellent collection, starting with Icons from the time of Rubljov, showing the beginnings of western style Portraits from the 18th century and then entering Russia's great cultural period in the 19th and early 20th centuries: Repin, Levitan, Venezianov, Kuindzhi, Shishkin, see the exceptional Serov, go all the the Benois Wing including Soviet paintings, and do not miss the bookshops.

Worthwhile detour, buy a book or audio guide. I went on a Thursday afternoon (1pm-9pm opening hours) and surprisingly there was a long line of mostly Russian tourists to get in. But it moved fast enough.Tickets were ₽350 and I bought a guide book from one of the gift shops for ₽440. Most of the paintings listed in the book were on display but out of order. Photography quality was sound but unfortunately the descriptions were mostly a single paragraphs that comprised of a brief artist or subject biography. Still it had a good history of the building, the collections and was worthwhile enough to use while browsing the gallery.Inside the museum the directional signage was all bilingual as was the artist and title descriptions for the permanent collections. But other than that there was very little curation for either language until the Modern galleries. While the temporary collections were limited to Russian.As others have said there are some striking masterpieces in here that make it a memorable experience and a worthwhile detour from the usual tourist traps. I just wished the museum received more funding as there were a number of rooms that could do with a new coat of paint and floor polish.

Humbled by my ignorance of Russian art. Cannot believe how little I knew of Russian art and how impressive it was to see the history of Russian art. Given the tremendous geography of Russia, its art stretches from the far east to Persia and Cairo with dozens of wars in between! The modern artists were most impressive with Russian artists matching teh skills of Western Impressionists and other avant garde movements of the 19th and 20th Centuries.

State Russian Museum. Amazing art from Russian artists, all kinds, painting, sculpture, decorations, enamels, bone carving, textiles. The museum is huge and would take days to see it all. The entrance is via a small door on the side, and you have to go through a mazelike basement to get to the first floor where the exhibitions begin. The price is a very reasonable 350 rubles (about $7).

Impressed about Russian art. Being honest: I didn't know anything about Russian art before going to this museum and after I went I realized that Russian art is as good as the western european art. Some times, better. Travellers usually think about visiting the Hermitage, but once in Saint Petersburg, the Russian Museum is a must see!
I Great museum of Russia Art. I you wants to know more about Russian History and see all the ages of Russian art, go to Russian Museum and get an audio guide. Getting in was easy, line was minimal.

"A living memory...". "...this artistic store to be a living memory of the regal concerns of the one, who so ardently loved the Motherland and has dedicated all His life to serve it." This sentence closed the order of the Russian Tsar Nikolai II on the foundation of the State Russian Museum in the memory of His father Alexander III of Russia. After so many years this place remains 'the living memory' of the whole epoch of Russian art, where every exhibit renders the twists of destinies, professional pathways, failures and successes... which are as captivating as their artistic expression! Indeed, the memory is living :)

interesting colection of communist art. besides the expected collection of old russian art, church art, treasures of the royal family and Russian nobelty, there is a rich collection of arts generated during the comunist period, where classical motives were adjusted to the "red" idealogy - recruited art. the ceramics generated in that period is decorated with the sickle and hammer and there is a lot of abstacr ceramics pretending to be tough and useful but these are pieces of modern "decadent" art. the modern sculptures are very modern and similar to European exprionists. very interesting and atractive.

Don't miss the Hermitage, but do save some time for the incredible Russian Museum. Another incredible collection that goes beyond paintings and sculptures, up to decorative arts, furniture and objects from the 20th Century and Russia's Soviet times. The fine arts collection is also completely breathtaking - unfortunately for those who don't speak Russian, like most museums in the country, the texts and captions are mostly Russian only.

We really enjoyed this museum!. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum although we had to find a way to get in because of renovations. I am glad we had the time to visit and made the effort to slip away from the crowd. The surrounding park is lovely as well.

Stunning Collection. Shouldn't Be Missed.. Quite impressive and should be on the list of things to do while in St. Petersburg. Makes one understand that there are many masters way beyond the more well publicized artists of the past and present. Wasn't overly crowded for a Saturday and central to other historical sites. The interior is also beautiful and varies from room to room. Some of the beautiful work are actually the chandeliers and details applied to the walls as well as the ceilings. The bookstore offers an affordable catalog of the collection should you want a lifetime memory of this wonderful museum.
A complete course on Russian art. Particularly enjoyed the avant garde period. A nice collection of iconostasis as well. A good way to escape the tour masses as well.
Different from the others. This museum focused more on the Russian artists which was very interesting, informative and enjoyable.

Terrific surprise. This museum doesn't get hyped in guide books, yet it is by far the best art museum here. Very little English signage but it is all arranged chronologically so one easily gets the gist of it. Wonderful to witness the way broader art currents affected Russian artists, and the turbulent history of Russia as reflected in its art. We spent an afternoon here and wished we'd allotted a day.

Great beautiful building with God exhibits. This lesser known museum is a real sleeper and well worth the visit. Not that crowded but full of terrific stuff it is both educational and enjoyable to visit. They have periodic seats to rest weary bones, well lit galleries, a good gift shop and a decent restaurant and gift store. Although clearly not as popular as the hermitage ,fabrege and other museums it is important as an outpost of Russian history and should be seen
Alternative to Hermitage. The Hermitage is hopelessly overrun with tourists, many in groups making it difficult to get around. The Russian Museum is quieter with some fabulous Russian Art.

A gem.. This was by far my favorite museum in St Petersburg. It is much quieter than the Hermitage and hosts a collection of Russian art from the Middle Ages to the 20th c. Paintings, furniture, ceramics... Not to be missed.

Leisurely stroll through history. This museum is a gem for the Russian people. Loved that there were no crowds and we could go through the museum at our own pace. Loved the outsized paintings with a place to sit and observe them on a bench. The art was outstanding and the grounds were serene.

Surprisingly Unique !!. Before visiting the Russian state Museum, I wasn;t so much into museums and into art in general. However after visiting this museum. it totally changed my perspective. The paintings are mindblowing. you feel as if they are talking to you. This is a must visit in st Petersburg. Russian art is great and it will exceed your expectations.Note: The Museum offers discounts on tickets for students, (via students card)

Superb collection of Russian art. Superb collection of Russian art from all ages. I specially loved the late XIX and early XX century collections (Malevich, Kadinsky etc). The Soviet-era art was unknown to me and very beautiful and expressive.
A must see if you like russian history. Very good museum, the ticket is really cheap (moree than another museum in Piter) and you can see and learn a lot of the Russian/soviet histoey

Beautiful museum with amazing art collection!. I visited museum with my children and opted out of the tour as we prefer to wonder around on our own. Russian Museum has an amazing collection of paintings and sculpturs by Russian artists. My favorites are Bruilov and, Ayvasovsky. You can spend a long time studying expressions on the face of the people on "The Last day of Pompei" by Karl Bruilov and amazing details of the backgrounds and realistic colors of the water of Ayvazovskiy paintings.

Amazing collection. From Icons to Malevich - is a name of the book I bought at the Russian museum which exactly captures the essence of this great place that has collection of Russian masters from 8 century to today. If you have time 3-4 hours for one museum visit in St. Petersburg - choose this place
alive russian art. we had a great impression from the museum about the culture and history of russian artists. İt deserves to spend your valuable time, evrything was made with high spirit :)

Don't miss it if you want to understand Russia. My wife guided me here, she is a professional artist. I was completely new to Russian art, so I am grateful. The Russian Museum is a must go place if you want to understand Russia. I became a big fan of Serov. His painting "The rape of Europe" was shockingly beautiful.

Don't miss opportunity to view Russian artists. Why go and see Italian & French art at the very crowded Hermitage, when you can see works by Russian masters. See/learn something new. Very nice museum with impressive works.
A must. Don´t miss this museum. You´ll see the Works of all the Russian painters. Wonderful Museum in a beautiful palace
a gem. this museum is the best place to see Russian art, from icons to contemporary. the galleries are in a former palace and are just spectacular. GO!!

Don't wast your time here. This was one of the most disappointing stop while I was in St Petersburg. Yes, it's another check off the list. But had I spend more time else where even in places like the Political museum it would have made my experience much better.
Best Place to Experience Russian Art. Love all the huge, life-sized paintings of the peasants, soldiers, politicians, generals, emperors and empresses.
unique. Russian art at its best. Rarely represented on such a scale and quality outside of Russia. A must for anyone interested in Russian culture/history

There is not any other Museum that I have visited in Europe that compares.. The sheer size of the museum is overwhelming and the displays are so well laid out that they are easy to maneuver (so long as you do not visit during tourist season). St. Petersburg is nothing like the rest of Russia as it is truly a tourist town. People are welcoming as much as any Russian will welcome an American and it is easy to get around by bus or taxi.

Amazing. As an American expat working in Moscow, I had opportunity to see numerous areas of the country. The State Russian Museum is a must for anyone traveling to SP.
