It holds much history and culture of this great country. What impressed me most about the museum are the docents who cherish their positions to share. If you take the time to learn a few key Russian words such as please and thank you, they will reward you with great effort to show you what they cherish...
Art by Russian artists. Fabulous works of art by Russian artists. Some are enormous and a must to see after you have visited the Hermitage

To become au fait with the Russian Fine Art &Culture. I recommend this Museum to everyone who would be sick of long queues and crowd in the Hermitage and to every single one who wants to become more familiar with the Russian Fine Art as the Russian preserves this type of Art. You do not have to stand near each painting and scrutinise it. Just take a quick walk round all the halls to understand how Russians were tending to paint several centuries ago. It is really worth your money.

Not to be missed!. We took over 7 hours to visit this museum - there is so much to see that we ended up having to run thru the Gloriously decorated 2nd floor rooms in the main Palace - the art in the more modern sections was completely outstanding. We opted for the expensive - but well worth it - audio guides - which explains our speed. Each painting that is numbered is described in extensive detail, and then the biography of the artist is also provided. There are some standout images - particularly the paintings by Serov. His ability to give his subjects a specific identity (not always the one they would have chosen) was incredible. I was also very impressed by how 'uncrowded' the halls of the massive museum were. While you weren't alone - you definitely didn't have to fight for viewing space with hordes of tour groups and their guides. A wonderful museum, glorious art, some surprising new to me artists to discover - and a very reasonable price. Definitely a 5 star day.

A feat for the eyes. The day we visited the museum, there were few visitors - compared with the Hermitage - and so we had the space to walk around at our leisure and learn much from the paintings. An English language audio guide was invaluable, giving the background to many of the exhibits, which range from the earliest icons to the latest art. The café caters for Russians, which means the food is freshly prepared and, for the high quality, less expensive than on Nevsky Prospect.

Great way to learn of Russian art, culture and history. Russian museum is a great journey to Russian culture and art.The museum houses a huge collection of Russian art, starting with ancient icons up to modern art. It takes around 2 hours to see the highlights.If you are interested in modern art only, you should enter the museum not from the front, but from the Griboyedov canal. There is another entrance (Griboyedov canal,2) to the museum there which will bring straight to the beginning of the collection of Russian avantgarde art. The Museum is closed on Tuesday

An essential flavour of Russian life and history. Marvellous collection, especially of modern Russian painters of the 19th and 20th centuries, ceramics, furniture, folk art, old paintings, an incredible collection of rare icons, and much more, in a stunningly beautiful palace building. Really worth the effort and not to be missed even if you are faggedout by the Hermitage already!

Do only if you have plenty of time..hermitage way better. nice visit . Do not use St-Petersburg Card... it is a waste of money and most important attraction in St-Petersburg are not included (hermitage, peterhoff palace, Catherine palace, imperial porcelain museum, and many other sites; you will either only recuperate 30% to break even...

Much easier than the Hermitage. The Russian Museum is a wonderful place to visit and I would highly recommend it to any foreigners (and Russians too). Many people from the West have never heard of these Russian artists and are very pleasantly surprised. It's much smaller than the Hermitage and as a result, a lot less intimidating. The crowds are smaller and the whole thing is much less exhausting. Read a little about the history of the building and the area surrounding it before going - it's very interesting.

Very beautiful. The museum is very spacious and well organized. The enormous halls and rooms give the place a majestic feeling you can'[t experience except in those museums at St. Petersburg. Highly recommended to visit this museum!

Very good place overall. Art is just awesome. So many pictures are just memories from the childhood of any Russian - museum visits while with your kindergarten fellows, school books illustrations, pictures from children's books, scenes from the history readings. I spent almost 15 minutes by Ilya Repin's "Session of the State Council" which is just a-w-e-s-o-m-e.The museum shop is also great - there're a lot of famous paintings' copies sold there so if you really like it, just buy your own copy.
A Must Do. Fantastic place with wonderful art and changing temporary displays. Really good value for money. All museums etc. have free cloakrooms for coats.

Worth visiting. Come for the best in terms of Russian icons, crafts and paintings of the 19th century and the Russian Avant-Garde.1 May - 30 September the Summer Garden is open daily (except Tuesday) from 10.00 a.m. till 10.00 p.m.(entrance until 9.30 p.m.)Free entranceThe Summer Palace of Peter the Great is closed for the restoration works. Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday – 10:00 a.m. – 6:00 p.m. Thursday – 1:00 p.m. – 9:00 p.m.The Museum remains closed on Tuesdays!

the best russian art ever seen. it all depends what you like. we concentrated in the 20th century russian art, influenced by europe but so totally russian and powerful. we really liked it. Many of these artists are really shown outside of Russia and therefore , in some ways, this is the most interesting museum one can see as we cannot see anywhere else. We intend to go back to look at Russian art from earlier periods as well.

An absolute must. Reserve 3-4 hours for your visit. Excellent museum next to a nice park and the Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood. So it is wise to plan visiting both of these places. But reserve at least 3 hours for the Russian museum. The 18th cent. portraits of honoured aristocrats - you can give it a miss. The real gems are of course Bryullov and Aivazovsky, and Shishkin and Repin, and Serov and Vasnetsov. But don't stop there. The XX cent. halls are also worth visiting. Petrov-Vodkin, Deineka... Soviet art collection is very much recommended. And don't forget the museum shop!

Pure Russian and amazing art works. This is a truly great collection of art from early icons to great paintings. Some of these works kept me spellbound and many are of cultural and historic significance. Try not miss this museum and don't get so carried away that you miss the Kadinski exhibition.On the downside: Russia has lots of money for war and the destabilisation of the Ukraine, but art is not high on the Kremlins agenda.This museum requires work on its building and exhibition space and their lighting is truly bad. The staff told me that the little money allowed for art goes mainly to the Hermitage, it being the great flagship. I would recommend this museum to anyone. Great Art!!!!
Interesting. Positively surprised. Definitely interesting, full of Russian art and only...Traditional classic museum full of paintings and wide range of crafts.

You have to be into Russian art. It's a beautiful building and filled with Russian art and lots of sculptures. I loved the second floor of the main building because of the building itself. These paintings weren't my thing, but doesn't mean the place deserves a bad rating.

The Russian Museum. My dear English teacher asked me to write review about Saint-Petersburg sights for foreign people. It is good time to do it because of the high season for tourists. Let's start! This Museum was opened in 1898. Nicholas the Second issued the edict about establishment of the special museum “Russian Museum of Alexander the Third”.Museum is situated in the Center of Saint Petersburg. It will be very convenient to find it. In this museum there are many really wonderful pictures of Russian artists: Ayvazovskiy I.K., Repin E.A., Brullov K.P., Shishkin I.I. and others. My favorite picture is “ The Wave” by Ayvazovskiy I.K. Many pictures are very big, it is amazed You its majesty and power.You can buy a special device and You should stop near a picture and press the number, which is under the picture and the voice of guide will tell You about artist and the creation history of this work of art.If You are a big fan of art You should go to this Museum – it will be very interesting for You.
A little disappointed. I was expecting to see a lot of Russian art, but it cannot compete with the Tretyakov gallery in Moscow.
Extraordinary. Another true treasure in st Petersburg, as well as Hermitage, ...... a wonderful place to visit, a very GOOD organisation INSIDE thé muséum ....

Very Impressionable!. I was very pleasantly surprised by my visit to the Russian Museum. They have a very good collection of Russian Icons, and the Peredvizhniki (Wanderer) movement is well represented. All of those were very worth seeing. But I was very pleasantly surprised by the outstanding collection of Russian 20th century pieces that are included in the museum. The pieces are organized chronologically by movement, and there are descriptions on the wall of each room in the 20th century wing that help you to understand what characterize the currents of that group of painters in that era. It is rather pedagogical, helping you understand the development of Russian art in the 20th century from Art Nouveau, Blue Rose symbolists, early Abstractionists, the Knave of Diamonds group, Cubists, Futurists, clear into and through the Soviet era. A fascinating journey through one of the most interesting developments in contemporary art history. And it's a major plus that you can see the 20th century wing without having to buy a separate ticket (unlike the Hermitage, the Tretyakov, and the Pushkin Gallery, which require separate ticket for the modern art galleries).

visit in april 2015. we visit the museum in cold days . the museum is very friendly and as it was eastern it was a bit full with visitors. you leave you jacket + bags and baby chair to cloak room as you always do in russia . the pictures and all shows are really magnificent .
Beautiful..... Watched the guards trooping around front. Bit like our trooping of the colour.... The Museum is gorgeous.

For Russian art Lovers. If you adore Russian art or want to explore some part of its wealth it's the place to go. All in all The Russian State Museum is placed in 3 different buildings - soo really a lot to explore! As the Hermitage presents masterpieces from around the world, here you will experience the touch from only Russian marvellous art!

Russian Art. I don't know Russian art history, and it didn't keep my from enjoying the experience. This is a window into Russian history. The interior building and displays were lovely, too.If you know what you'll be getting and that it's a lot of the beautiful but unknown, its worth the experience. Patience, willingness and stamina are necessary, I think. Probably not for those who don't enjoy artistry. I did need a nap afterwards, since it takes 4-5 hours, at least, to really go through the whole museum.{ September 2012 visit }

must see. the collection of truly great paintings is limited, true, but a handful of masterpieces are there, a good collection of traditional russian art and then the palace itself. but why do foreigners always have to pay more, not a very welcoming policy, not known in my own country

must see. This museum was less crowded than the Hermitage and offered a real insight into the russian culture.The Hermitage is amazing, but it does contain things that you would find in any number of european museums.

One of the less well-known Museums in St Pete's: well worth a visit. This museum has some relatively little known Russian art, and can be a real eye opener for West European visitors. For those who find the Hermitage queues intimidating, I'd heartily recommend this as a back-up option.

Proud Russian Heritage and arts exhibition. Visited on 3 Oct 2012. Back then I couldn't find where exactly was the entrance until I walked near by the small entrance on the right of the main gate. Nevertheless, inside the museum are collections of many national paintings including Jesus Christ at the Cross, Eastern Orthodoxy depictions, monuments of artists and sculptures of David, Venus, and other Italian style sculptures. Outside, sits the TALL STATUE OF PUSHKIN, the most renowned Russian Writer!

No Monets, Pissarro's Rembrandts - Just loverly Russian Paintings.. This is what you come to see when you visit another countries Art Gallery. Their paintings, local artists and their history. All this is here, and beautifully presented.This is my type of Art Gallery; real paintings- an exhibition of skill and talent, and showing real life in this part of the world. Thank heavens this Modern Art 'stuff' has not yet reached SPB - where handfuls of good paint are thrown at a wall, floor of ceiling!! Here are beautiful works of art. I visited the State Gallery in Moscow too, and again excellent Russian works by painters I have never heard of - but I loved their paintings.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia

Under-rated and Excellent - must see Russian greats. The State Museum is grossly under-rated and deserves more attention when you put together your St Petersburg itinerary.You will find that while the Hermitage focuses on artwork from outside Russia, the State Museum has some amazing pieces. Must see pieces include Aivozovsky's Ninth Wave and The Wave, Repin's Barge Haulers, Polenov, Makovsky, Myasoyedov, and my favourite the brilliant Shishkin.Some very bleak subjects but typical of the art of the times in Russia.Apart from the great art, the museum is normally far-less crowded than many other venues in St Petersburg. We had a nice stroll across a snowy park filled with snowmen on the way to the museum.Visited February 2013.
Great art collection and craft collection. Museums own a lot of famous pictures by most significant Russian artists. What is more there is great collection of ivory and wooden carvings.

Place where national culture is materialized. We just love art and conside it to be a perfect reflection of culture. Rich national culture - rich art gallery exhibiting local artists. Russian Museum is the place to see quite impressive art works.

Need to visit. Collection of Russian art from old Russion icon painters ( Rublev, Ushakov) to Avangard (Malevich) 20 th century. Russian painting, sculpture, the graphic, decorative and folk arts from the 10-th century to the present day. To understand all the historical events in this pictures and to be admired you need 3 days and more. But a few hours are also enough to have the imagination about the first national museum in Russia, opened its doors in 1889 year.

Worth a Visit. The State Russian Museum is definitely worth a visit if you can while in St. Petersburg. It's right next to the Church on the Spilled Blood. The building itself of the State Russian Museum is a beautiful Neoclassical former palace of one of the Romanov grand dukes. The exhibits in this museum are first rate and some of the opulent rooms are fascinating as well. The crowds are also less than in the more famous Hermitage. The park in the back of the museum provides a quiet oasis and is pleasant to visit. Expect to spend at least two hours for your visit to get an appreciation of the museum and its collection.

A Nice Experience in Russian Art. The State Russian Museum is located "Art Square" featuring a Statue of Alexander Pushkin. This magnificent sprawling building houses a wonderful collection of Russian art. The Hermitage it is not, but that was not a problem for us. We just enjoyed what we witnessed here. When you enter get the mobile audio tour system they provide for a little extra. Get there early to avoid crowds. Even my wife enjoyed(not normal)

Stunning Russian Art. This was a wonderful experience. We spent hours here looking at paintings by artists we'd never seen before. The building itself is of course fabulous and not as overwhelming as the Hermitage however it is the art that is the star here. For us in particular the late 19th and 20th century art represented by people such as Vrubel. It is a must along with the Hermitage and easier to take in!

Wonderful collection of Russian art.. the wonderful thing about this as well as other galleries in Russia is one proximity to the art. I was looking forward to the Soviet art but unhappily that masterpiece of Stalin addressing in party congress was not on display when I visited. Maybe Putin has had it put back by now.

Russian masterpieces. The history of russian art from icon painting to the canvasas of soviet painters - development of russian pictorial art spread out before you. Very impressive huge canvases by Aivazovskiy is just something one must see at least once..I would define the magnifisent collection as the richest heritage of russian art - dont forget to put this museum to your list of places to see in St Petersburg.

Not so impressed. Perhaps it was wrong to head here straight after the Hermitage but as a result, it kind of paled by comparison in my head. Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I did it on another day. But the bottom line is - if you only have a couple days in the city, spend some proper time at the Hermitage and avoid the State Russian Museum altogether, it's a no-contest.

A Formal State Museum. Large paintings, portraits, and lots of gold on the frames. Not so different from most museums, well the old ladies who sit in each room are always there in all old Soviet countries. In Bulgaria, they waited until you walked in to the exhibit room to turn on the lights, and would then turn them off as soon as you left. My father would have approved.Don't try to look at everything on the walls,( overload),but do look AT the walls and ceilings this was, after all, a palace in its former life.

Great at every single visit. I first visited the Museum in 1999 and subsequently at every visit to St. Petersburg. It's just that good. The Ermitage never really impressed me (me being not an art lover), but somehow the Russian Museum hits a note with me. What's more, I find I look at the same pictures every time. The portrait of Shishkin, Suvorov in the alps, the Saporog Cossacks,... and yet I never tire of it.THe first time I visited, I had an SPB guide book with a lot of stuff on the Russian Museum, which was good, later I visited without a guidebook or anything - this time, though, I decided not to be cheap and went for the audioguide. More expensive than the entrance fee (but of course cheap in real-life terms) this was a good thing, highly recommended.On practical issue - the museum tends to get full quickly, and especially in winter the limiting factor are the wardrobes, so expect queues from midday on. OTOH; this means that if you come early, you'll be very comfortable. Life in Russia tends to get going around 11am (I stay with friends and they seem to believe to life in GMT time zone) - so try to be there early!!Time-wise we were there about 3h, this included a snack in the café, though (not really recommended). I could have stayed longer, but my 12yo was exhausted. The fact alone that he held up for so long speaks for the museum, though.

a bit crowdd. Not far from Palace Square (and surrounded by decent restaurants), is the most excellent Mikhaelovski Palace more commonly known as the Russian Museum. This was my second favorite museum in Russia - behind only the Hermitage. First of all, it's in a palace beautiful in its own right. Second, you're not as likely to be subject to the mass crowds at the Hermitage. (Although you will run into the occasional tour gruop or students led by a teacher)Most importantly, it is filled with beautiful art by artists you've likely never heard of. Some you may have, if you've studied Russian history (Repin and the like), but Schedrin, Ivazovski, Roerich - the list goes on and on. This isn't just boring icons -beautiful seascapes, modern art and excellent impressionism is intermixed with your standard portraits and well-done marble work.When you leave you're treated to a beautiful view of the Church on Spilled Blood (Spas na Kravi) to your right.

Russian. I believe that all of the pieces of art in this museum are from native Russians. I think that I only knew 2 paintings before I went in but I have some new favorites. I brought my camera in and took lots of pictures. I also loved how some of the paintings were as tall as the walls which are taller than 10 feet in places.

...the heart of Russia will not forget you. My husband and I visited this museum in October, 2014. The cloakroom and toilet rooms were modern and clean, and the exhibits were well displayed. Several famous ones that I anticipated were missing, (perhaps for cleaning or on loan?), so that was a disappointment. There were some fabulous portraits of some parliamentary figures, and that was really interesting. Again, too bad there was no information about these paintings at the gift shop. It was nice to see the palace that Alexander II had visited (to convince his cousin to accept his morganic wife) just immediately before his assassination and the stair case is a marvel. We recommend this museum for its collection.

Impossible to understand Russia without this museum. The masterpieces on display are jewells in Russian arts. They depict rich cultural and historical heritage, often in dramatic way. Grand canvases are especially magnificent.

Icons and Aivasovsky. Well worth a day's visit. Particularly the bottom floor with stunning icons and the upper floor with Aivasovsky's "Wave" make for a memorable visit. The guides are interesting to listen to even if you don't understand Russian. Their love for these masterpieces is clear in their gestures, facial expressions and tone of voice. Some are so excited it sounds like they are almost singing.

Russian Museum - St. Petersburg. Fantastic collection of Russian Art. There are over 400,000 paintings, ranging from historic icons to modern art of the twentieth century. These are all works by Russian artists. Museum is well designed, easy to get around and is 'warm and inviting'.Entrance fee was 350 rubles. There is a nice cloak room, museum shop, refreshments and bathroom. Well worth the visit!Jon Lefeber

Hermitage first, then this one--DONT SKIP THIS ONE. For history buffs, this museum will move you chronologically through the centuries of Russian history. The dramatic shifts in history are well-represented. One moves between "Old Rus" rooms (icons) and "Imperial Russia" (the European-style rooms), for example, and "Imperial Russia"/early 20th c to "Soviet style" art. The shifts are shocking; the presentations make a big impact. A long hall of "craft," again presented "through the centuries," was excellent. Don't miss this museum.

More interesting than the Hermitage. The Hermitage seems to be the top of everyone's list of art museums to see in St. Petersburg, but in my opinion, The Russian Museum was far more interesting and a good place to learn about Russian history and culture. All of the art work in this museum is by Russian artists. The collection spans Russian history from the early times to the present. Although most of the collection consists of paintings, there are small collections of other media including sculpture, wood carvings, and lacquer-decorated objects. The paintings by Russians are simply amazing. They depict important moments in history, famous characters, as well as ordinary life and people. Many of the paintings are enormous and cover and entire wall of the gallery. I found that touring this museum gave me a good introduction to a cross-section of Russian history as well as a taste of the complex soul of the Russian people. This will be the first place I re-visit if I go back to St. Petersburg.
Excellent. One of the best museums in Russia, not even St.-Petersburg, where you could find most beautifull creatures of great artists.

A different feel from the Hermitage. This is where you see art by Russian artists. I wasn't familiar with them, but am very glad I went. You would probably want to allow at least two hours there, depending on your level of interest. Most of the souvenir shops sell videos of the museum, but they are not in the system the US uses. You can get programs on the internet to convert it. I haven't had time to do that yet, but I was so impressed with the collection that I wanted something to remember it by. It is close to Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood, so you can combine visits for a half day of touring.
One day is not enough.. One day is not enough. You can be lost there. Great museum, but you need hours. And the entrance in the park can be closed in winter times - take another one from the canal.

Impressive collection!. This State Russian Museum collection is housed in the impressive neoclassical Mikhailovskiy Palace and traces the complete history of Russian art, from magnificent 11th century icons to contemporary works. The palace itself (former imperial residence built for Grand Duke Michael Pavlovich) is a sight to see as many of the halls retain their original opulent Italianate interiors. We enjoyed our time at the Russian Museum as much as our time at the Hermitage and WITHOUT the huge crowds associated with the Hermitage.

Wonderful variety of art and craft. We visited on a Sunday in late October, when the museum can get very busy with local people and groups of children exploring the place. The busyness was not a problem - just part of the experience. There are some fascinating things to see. All exhibits have an English translation along with Russian, so it is easy to discover what is being seen. I particularly enjoyed the section with some art-crafts - lacquered boxes, lace, wooden toys and models - but other may prefer more 'classic' art. What you won't find here is anything covering the Second World War or later - perhaps that is displayed in a different museum. We went to the small cafe in the basement and had great soup for lunch. Both of the ladies serving spoke a few words of English, and were helpful, so it didn't feel too difficult making an order.

Impressive art and (interior)architecture.. A visit to the Russian Museum is very recommended. If you want to explore more Russian Art than this visit is a must be. The Russian art is fantastic, I have never seen such a vast collection except Repin. The interior is also overwhelming. Try to see what materials are used. The main staircase is also impressive. I took many fabulous pictures with my new camera Nikon D810 and oh it was worthwhile. Hermitage and Russian Museum, both are worth visiting. You can say both are excellent but only different more complementary.

Russian fine art.. I have been to many of the major museums ,and this was my first visit to an all "Russian" museum. i love it. Highly recommend getting to this one. i loved most of the works & paintings there which are really something to see , enterance cost 350 rubles per person.

must see place. one of the best and must see place in Saint Petersburg. Wonderfull plcace with biggest collection of russian art in every field from icons till modern art. Beautiful Mikhailovsk's palace. You will enjoy this luxuriest atmosphere of russian emperors.

Authentic Russian. Finally something really Russian, after the Hermitage which ignores all that is Russian this Museum gave us a great impression of the development of the Russian arts. We found it interesting that most of the developments that took place in Europe in the 13th/14th century took quite some time until they arrived on the canvas of the Russian artists. The collection is unfortunately not as well restored as the one in the Hermitage. Also the displays and the rooms could use some renovation. I hope they invest a bit of money to keep these unique pieces of art.

We preferred this one to the Hermitage... believe it or not :). Great collection of Russian art. The Hermitage has art from around the world so we found it very interesting to see only Russian artist (or foreign artists that lived in Russia at least). We both agreed that this museum had a bigger impression on us than the Hermitage.

Uncrowned rival IMHO of the Hermitage.. The Russian artists of the 1880's and impressionists era are collected here. See for yourself if some of the massive sized paintings don't impress you more than the two small Davinci s in the Hermitage. Easy to get to and easy to do in a couple hours without the crowds.

Enjoyed my visit. I liked this museum. Some of the paintings were excellent. I am not too big on seeing every little thing on display as you can see from the time I spent there but I have to say I did enjoy this one.

Good Overview of Russian Painting with a Newly Renovated C19 and C20 Wing. The museum is uncrowded and, yes, the arrangement is chronological yet slightly confusing. Nevertheless, it is delightful and important. Particularly for anyone with a keen interest in nineteenth and twentieth century painting, the new installation helps connect the dots, so to speak, in the history of Russian art.Note that, like the Hermitage, you cannot re-enter the museum, although you can of course back track. So there is a cafe with light food near the present visitor entry and a full-service restaurant just before the exit. (At the Hermitage, you need to look for the Internet Cafe.) Plan to spend the greater part of a day in either museum.

Doesn't compare to the Hermitage. This was okay, but after seeing the Hermitage was not very impressed by the museum or the art. If you have to make a choice - choose the Hermitage. Plus, the way this place is designed is very confusing. It is like a big maze. I would not really recommend this museum.

Not only Mondrian and Kandinsky. This museum was a great sorprise. I went with no knowledge about russian art and i was very glad to discover the rich history of it. The Museum is really big, but have a cronological order. And all the rooms and pictures have exhaustive explanations in english.The souvenir and book store is very complete and cheap, so you can go deep with a good book.

Lots of history !. Nicely situated just a few minutes walk off the Nevsky Prospekt, this museum is well worth a visit. Lots of information and exhibits showing some of the history of this big country with such a long and hard history.

A delightful surprise. After the mobs at the Catherine Palace and the Hermitage, we were delighted with the beautiful and uncrowded Russian Museum. The art, although previously unknown to us, is gorgeous and the Russian impressionists rival those of France.
We actually enjoyed this hidden treasure more than our visit to the Hermitage.
Do not miss this museum. The art is magnificent! We had not heard of most of the artists because one generally does not get to see these paintings. We were awed by the quality of the artists.

Superb. A superb collection of Russian art, beautifully and thoughtfully displayed. Probably a better presentation than the Hermitage on a bright day. Well worth a visit, although finding the front entrance can be a challenge. Once you have twisted and turned through the basement corridors/maze you emerge into a lovely gallery.

Tick the box by visiting but there are more enjoyable places. It's a kind of a "must-see" landmark that every concierge will tell you to stop by at. If you love Repin et al, then you'll spend a very enjoyable 3-odd hours here but overall, it feels a little bit soulless and you're better off seeing the grandeur of Tsars at the Hermitage. So yes, if you're in the city for 3 days, you're going to end up here anyway but if you've only got a day to cram sightseeing into, there are better places.

See this as well as the Hermitage. I loved visiting the Hermitage but the Russian Museum is very worth your limited tourist time.As other reviewers have said:- you can't see this art anywhere else and some of it is astounding- it is a lot less crowded than the Hermitage- there is a nice progression from icons to modern I wish we had more time, as we wound up literally running through the Museum as it closed down around us. Allow more time than you think, because you'll need it.

Great Russian art--maybe skip the Hermitage. This is a fascinating and fantastic museum of Russian art. The works may be especially interesting to Americans and Western Europeans since many of these artists are unknown outside of Russia. If you are really pressed for time in St. Petersburg, consider skipping the Hermitage since the art in the museum is available in many other places in the world.

Fascinating museum - much better managed than the Hermitage!. This museum is really fascinating and gives you a great insight into Russian art over the centuries. It is very manageable and easy to navigate - a big contrast to the Hermitage which was a living nightmare. This museum has far fewer guests and can be done within a couple of hours. Highly recommend getting the audioguide as you won't be able to understand anything otherwise.

Huge art gallery of Russian stuff. We spent a couple of hours, and saw only a tiny proportion of the pieces on display. The tempory exhibits of glass & porcelain were impressive & very well displayed.

Amazing art collection. I was absolutely amazed by how vast and rich the collection is. I have been in the museum for 5 and a half hours and didn't feel the time pass. Try to have several visits, it's very exhausting and almost impossible to see it all at once.

Russian immersion. Great to browse through Russian history from icon painting to after soviet art. I found it great to browse through and read all the Russian history on Wikipedia whilst I was seeing the related art.

You Can't See This Anywhere Else, So Go There. Over 100 rooms of Russian art from icons to iconoclasts. There were at least 20 artists we learned about that we found extraordinary (courtesy of our guide Olga from Marina Wilson tours) and none of this beautiful work is known outside the country it seems. For those who love impressionists, don't miss "Moonlit Night on the Dnieper" by A.I. Kuinji. For more traditional excellence, Ilya Repin is most famous but we were also taken with Aivazovsky's maritime scenes, Rokotov's portraits and Rublev's icons. There are many more, so come and see something Russian while you are here.

Best collection of Russian art in the world. After the size and grandeur and crowds of the Hermitage, this was a relaxing few hours to browse Russian art. After all, we were in Russia. After entering through a small door and negotiating somewhat of a maze we did manage to get through the museum in a few hours, albeit not in detail. Only Russian art here but some excellent and large works from Renaissance times and some interesting Soviet era art. Worth it for the price.

My favorite museum in St Petersburg - Repin. I have a particular fondness for Ilya Repin who is well displayed here but I also love almost all things Russia. This is my favorite place. You won't have the brutal crowds of the Hermitage and its a wonderful place. Please take the time to visit this museum.

Superb!. The Russian painting has started relatively late, and while the rest of Europe was developing art for centuries. the Russians did it in a few decades. This museum displays the fantastic collection of Russian masters, showing that there wasn't lack of talent between Russian artists and there are incredible paintings all over the museum. If you are not familiar with th Russian art this museum is highly recommended!

Some amazing large paintings?... There are many cultural attractions in St.Petersburg Russia...92 that I know of!This is worth a visit to see Russian art and there are some very impressive pieces worth seeing that alone justify the price of admission. Plan on minimum 3 hours but recommend 5 hours and take your time. Upon first entering you will see some large pieces that seem like they are about 120 square feet each! One wonders how the accuracy could be so good on such a large canvas. But then again this is Russia...a much misunderstood country and one of great achievements that become lost in the vestiges of politics.

Wished we could have had a bit more time. We were running out of time and just managed a few rooms in this museum but found it very interesting. Very different to what one sees in the other sights in St Petersburg. Russia artworks with a lot of historical significance. So much to see and so little time.....

The place to go for Russian art. As I've said in my previous review, when it comes to the Hermitage, it's certainly not a place to admire paintings, with far too many distractions. On the other hand, the State Russian Museum is just the place to go if you wish to concentrate solely on the beautiful paintings and sculptures. All of the important names are under a single roof, my favourite part of the galleries being the displays of works of Aivazovskiy, Andreyevich, Repin and some more Malevich, though his famous Black Square is in Moscow's New Tretiakov Gallery. It's manageable to walk through in one session.Only two nuissances: higher prices of entrance tickets to foreigners and some parts of the gallery being closed because of the renovation so instead of doing a round walk of the buildings you have to return and then go other way.

Excellent for art lovers. After the Hermitage with its poor lighting and mad crowds, this museum was so refreshing. Only the odd tour group, lots of quiet spaces to enjoy a vast historical sweep of Russian art. The audio guide was excellent too.
A Good Alternative to the Hermitage. A great collection of Russian art, and a better museum to visit than the Hermitage, which tends to be swarming with tourists.

Rarefied opportunity to view Russian paintings from the 19th and 20th century. Rarefied opportunity to view Russian paintings from the 19th and 20th century. The Hermitage is such a zoo these days, do yourself a favor if you are an art lover and spend a half day viewing this collection which you won't find anywhere else in the world.

A niche of world treasures. certainly the Russian repository for Egyptian, Greek and all world class historical art and artifacts. All a bit of a rush to get through but you just can't see everything and have to really scan everywhere as you go through.

Old style Museum. What a warren of rooms!
A large palace of many rooms, small collection works of Tatlin and Malevich making it worthwhile once they are located.

Worth a visit if you haven’t visited similar museum. Comparing to The Hermitage, the collection here is smaller, but there were much less people here, making it a lot easier to enjoy the artworks. Though, as I am not really an art addict, I found that the artworks become slightly repetitive as majority of the religious icons are of similar subject, but it is still worth a visit.

A Must. We found that every word of "Kiev October" was correct. We were interested mostly with Art in the end of the 19th &20th centuries. Amazing collection of paintings and sculptures. Mostly unknown to the us as "westerners" but all the same a splendid and rich collection in a beautiful setting. We were only in the exhibition in the Michilovsky Palace. There are more 4 buildings in the city! Something to expect for our next visit in this outstanding city.

If you are willing to learn something new.... WHY WORTH SEEING: as a tour guide, I must admit that not that many people know and care about Russian art. So if you are one of those people and you are not willing to spend your precious time trying to pronounce "Ay-va-zov-sky", then go to the Hermitage instead. On the other hand, if you want to see and learn something new and aviod crowds, go there. There were periods in Russian art, when we truly were like nobody else, and those periods are very well represented in this museum.Another great thing about this museum is that there is no BEST TIME TO VISIT or BEST WAY TO GET THERE, because it's never too crowded (just a couple Russian groups here and there) and it's located right next to the Church on Spillt Blood or Grand Hotel Europe and Nevsky prospect.MUST SEE: as I said before, there were periods in Russian art, when it was very different from every other art in the world. What you must see is the pieces created in those periods.The first one is represented by Russian icons, which in my opinion are perfect examples of something truly spiritual. All of them are located on the second floor.After that for quite a while Russian art was really influenced by Europe and we didn't create anything unique. All the pieces from that period is everything on the second floor, except for the icons, so I recommend to skip that.But then, starting the second half of the 19th century, something happened to our art and it became truly unique. Every artist had his own style and his own ideas. That's where the true Russian art comes and it starts on the 1st floor. Go around the whole 1st floor until you see the sign "To the Benois wing". Do not skip that wing and you will see some great Russian and Soviet art (19th-20th centuries).PLEASE NOTE:- The museum has wierd working hours. On Thursday is doesn't open till 1PM.- The museum is closed on Tuesday.- The museum is not really handicapt accessible, you have to go up the stairs in order to see anything.- They ask you to pay extra for taking photos, but nobody ever checks.- The cafe in the Benois wing is quite decent.
Worth a visit. Huge collection of Russian antique and contemporary art.Not to miss the astonishing " The Wave", by Aivazovsky.

Outshine the Hermitage (is that possible?). I'm actually not an art fan, but I love portraits. I had actually planned to see the Hermitage on Monday but found, to my chagrin, that Monday is their day off. So went to the Russian Museum by chance. Wow!Just around the corner from the Cathedral of the Spilled blood; short lines and not nearly as crowded as the Hermitage; fabulous collection of Russian painters including my favorite Brulov.Don't miss it!

Alla tours of ST. Petersburg, Russia. A group of us from Canada who were on a Baltic Sea cruise hired guides Katherine, the tour guide and Sergei, the bus driver, from Alla Tours to help us tour St. Petersburg for 2 days. We visited the Yusupov Palace, Peterhof Upper Garden and Fountains Park, the Catherine Palace, took the hydrofoil boat, visited the Hermitage, rode the subway, took a canal ride and had lunch at a Russian restaurant on the second day and then to the Church on the BLood. It was very much a packed 2 days. We walked a lot. Lunch had been included in the price of the tour for both days. Catherine was a very knowledgable guide, explaining many details and the history of the city to us. She made it an extremely interesting tour. St. Petersburg is a dynamic and big city and very busy. Lots of tourists and of course, lots of traffic. Sergei did an excellent job driving us around. He spoke little English but Katherine would interpret for him. They both appreciated the humour of us Canadians and were even laughing with us by the end of the second day. It was worth the price and all the walking. I would highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting St. Petersburg.

A great Russian art collection. I loved this museum. Not such a sumptuous and ornate building as the Hermitage and Winter Palace, but the building is still huge and impressive, and so is the collection. Scores and scores of rooms, with plenty of information in English as well as Russian. I concentrated on the paintings and there's far more here than I could take in during a 90-minute visit but I was so pleased to have gone. Lots of reminders of Russia's noble and grand past, spectacular landscapes, the violence of some of its history - and its very close links with Europe in the past few centuries and its shared artistic heritage as well as its own distinct traditions. Next time I'd come with a guide or at least hire an audio-guide, but for a first visit I was delighted just to soak up impressions and enjoy the sheer range of what's exhibited.

unexpected. I voluntarily skipped this museum on my first trip to St. Petersburg, and must admit I should have gone there rightaway. It is very instructive and gives an unbiased view on russian art and culture.
Russian art history at its best. Fantastic museum - if you are into Russian art, it will take you on a journey from the time when the first icons were created by local artists to the 20th century.

Smaller that Hermitage but nicely curated. This museum's collection of Russian art is well-curated and easy to navigate. We spent about 2 hours here and saw the best of the displays. The gift shop also is the place to buy authentic crafts.

Eye opening for many Westerners. The museum is set up chronologically, from religious art to current times. It is interesting to contrast what was happening in Russia with what was happening in Western Europe at the time, and see how religion and governments influenced the styles. It was also quiet during our visit, welcome after the crowds at other sites in St Petersburg. Maybe not a must see, but well worth it if you can find the time.

Wonderful icons and folk art. I enjoyed this museum more than the Hermitage, which is so crowded in high season that you can hardly walk through it. The Russian museum is much more manageable. There is a wonderful collection of Russian icons including a half dozen masterpieces. The folk art is also terrific.
russian realism. I left the Russian Museum bigger impression than the famous Hermitage. Beautiful Russian works, especially realism, the current exhibition of the first World War is authentic.

Great museum for Russian art. The State Russian Museum is around the corner from the Church on Spilled Blood. It houses only Russian art, and is much smaller and less crowded than the Hermitage. It's definitely worth visiting for a look into the history of Russian culture. Get the self-guided audio tour to understand the artists and the art.

You've seen everything else--now see RUSSIAN art and artists!. This museum contains over 400,000 works of Russian art--drawings, paintings, sculptures, icons, folk art, etc--from ancient to modern art--which is spread over four beautiful palaces in the center of St. Petersburg. It is definitely worth a visit if you have the time or the inclination. It gives a visitor a more complete view of Russia, its people, its history, and its methods of survival.
A Must For Anyone Wanting To See Russian Art. Starts with the earliest Russian times and continues through the 20th century. Takes about 2 hours to complete at an appropriate pace.

Worth a visit just for the Constructivist Art. This museum is not as popular as the Hermitage but offers some beautiful examples of contemporary Russian art - Malevich and Kandinsky are represented. In the relatively quiet surrounds and lack of crowds it makes a nice and easy detour after the more popular museums. Good bookshop and some interesting icons and Russian craft and rural art too.

A great national museum. The Hermitage has great art, but in summer the lines are very long and the crowds within are shoulder-to-shoulder. The Russian Museum has wonderful art from painters like Repin and Kramskoy, the hallways aren't crammed with tourists, and the site in Arts Square is lovely. Highly recommended.

Buy the audio guide or take a personal guide with you. Hardly anybody was at this museum (unilke the hectic Hermitage) but I found it much more interesting to see local Russian art when in Russia than a collection of foreign art in the Hermitage. Here you will see the first paintings in Russia, the largest, the history and some pretty famous pictures as well (ex. Kandinski). But for us, we needed someone to point out the important work or else we would not have seen all the elements at work and known about the history behind some of the masterpieces. The audio guide helped a lot but i suppose a real life guide would be good as well :)

Amazing art - especially the C20th wing. Pushes the Hermitage for top museum in this city of museums and galleries. We started with the outstanding collection of Russian art from the 20th century - to my mind the best part of the gallery... the crowds there are much less than in the main part of the palace...

One of the best museums in the world. I love State Russian Museum. It is often overlooked because of Hermitage - but it shouldn't be. It has unique collection of the 19th and 20th centuries Russian art, including such gems as Goncharova, Filonov, Roerich, and Kuindzhi - some of these you will hardly find anywhere else. The exhibit on the "other" Soviet art is also very interesting and creates a much more comprehensive picture of what was happening in the Soviet society.During my visit, the Museum had Roerich's exhibit on display which was simply stunning and included not only paintings but also letters, quotes from his writing, and sketches.Both permanent and temporary exhibits are also very well organized visually. Nothing distracts you from the artworks, and there are helpful and elegantly done descriptions on the entrance to each room. Sometimes I wish these were a bit more detailed, but that's the only thing I would improve.
Well worth a visit. Excellent special exhibit of political posters and paintings from the WW I era. Permanent exhibit of constructive paintings was also very interesting.

Russian Museum. It was interesting to see the Russian art and compare it with Western art, it is very different, but worth a visit, since it is near the Church of the Saviour on teh Spilled Blood one can visit both the same day.

Not to be missed. A superb collection of russian art. While not nearly as huge as the Eremitage, this museum is unique in that its collection consists solely of russian art. There were not large queues when we visited and the audio guide - available in various languages - was excellent and well worth the money. Photography is allowed. The collection spans everything from icons to russian constructivism and beyond. For me the most impressive sight I visited while in St Petersburg.

No queues great museum. The artwork on display in the main museum is stunning. Pay extra to take pictures. The entry is worth it for the Aivazorsky paintings alone but there are far more. lacquer work, folk art, lace, modern and old paintings. Cafe served good cakes and coffee. If you want to see Russian art forget the hermitage this the place.

REAL RUSSIA. You have done the Hermitage, now do not miss the REAL RUSSIA museum which is not overflowing with tourists & which allows you to stop & look without a tour guide plus her group smashing past you -pure joy! The paintings of early Russian history were an eye opener as was the group of school children been taught their history via paintings - nice one of the Czar holding his council,which again had a history group sitting down in front of it.The Benois wing contains painting from the 19th. & 20th. century which introduced me to a new set of artists plus of course they have Kandinsky and Malevich. Nice section on folk art plus a great statue of Ivan the Terrible. Pushkin statue as you go towards the museum with the usual pigeon either sitting on his head or on his arm. A different experience during your visit to St. Petersburg & a very good one.

Don't miss. Ok - this museum has the MASSIVE benefit of not being over run with Da Vinci hungry tourists. It also has amazing art work on display. I loved it here. Great building as well. Less overwhelming than the Hermitage. Also, so much of the art was new to me which made it really exciting. Loved it. The folk art section was great too - so interesting to see decorative art in a museum like this.

Delightful Surprise. We were very peased that we added a stop to the Russian Museum, it made us appreciate they had their own Cowboy and Indians (eskimos/Mongolian warlords etc,,,) going down as did we.Their style and taste were very similar to the rest of Europe but quite a few more Grand Pictures taking over the room that I would have guessed. Wood work was exquisite

Allow enough time. This place is much bigger than it looks. Enter on the canal side and see the special exhibit first. Be prepared with your map because it's a maze inside. Also be prepared to walk up and down stairs.

it is not the Hermitage, it's really Russian!. Visit this museum and you'll never be sorry for it. There are a lot of paintings of Russian artists:Aivasovsky, Syshkin,Vasnetsov and many others. It is placed in the wonderful Palace, that looks like a Russian estate,but much larger. There are no crowd of people here and you will ave a chance to spend pleasant time in a really impressive place.

A hidden gem. Most people travelling to St. Petersburg miss this wonderful museum because they spend so much time in the Hermitage. The wonderful artwork on display at this museum is well worth a visit. It's a fairly small museum in comparison to the Hermitage so it will only take half a day but you will not be disappointed.

Best of Russian Art under one roof. One cannot visit Russia without learning of its culture and the Russian Museum is a fantastic place to start. The museum encompasses art through the ages including handicrafts ranging from a wooden sculpture of mice carrying a cat tied up in ropes (the cat symbolizes the czar), ceramic toys (actually intact), traditional costumes and textiles to paintings that range from icons to the soviet period. It certainly is an impressive collection all housed in a former palace.Make the time and you will not be disappointed.

Very good!. Huge and full of interesting items: paint exposition as well handcraft from all Russia and different periods.Very nice to visit also the garden on the side of the palace…. don’t miss it: should be a pity!

Well worth a visit. The State Russian Museum is well worth a visit as well as the Hermitage if you have the time. It is quite different from the Hermitage and traces purely Russian art from very early times up to the present day. It starts with icons and illustrates well how art developed in Russia from then onwards. It is interesting how Russians have copied other European artists over the years. There is also some interesting Russian folk art. We were pleased we saw this interesting museum even though we had already spent many hours in the Hermitage. We liked being able to see some specifically Russian art whilst in Russia and, unlike the Hermitage, a lot of the artists were new to us.

A must when in Russia. The most fantastic place to experience Russian art at one place. What a collection! The contemporary section was full of great pieces quite far from the image of Soviet art I had before visiting the museum
Don't stop after The Hermitage. The State Russian Museum also has an interesting collection and the Mikhailovsky Palace is a lovely setting for it.

Less Crowded. The Russian Museum holds Russian artwork running from early icons through soviet junk. Some of the best and most famous artists of Russia are represented. The crowds are typically much smaller and the experience better than the Hermitage.

Keep returning there. I keep returning there and everytime there is something new I haven't seen or noticed before.There are no long queues to enter so if you cannot make it to State Hermitage - try Russian museum.

My favourite. This was determinately my favourite. Much smaller than the Hermitage it is more accessible. The best thing for me was the russian Art. There were paintings by artists I had never heard of and the more contemporary art was wonderful. There were 20th century paintings so evocative (look out for "The Queue" 0 hat I felt I had shared something wonderful. The Hermitage is brilliant, but most of the paintings in there were by artists whose work I had previously had the opportunity to see. This was something new. And if you appreciate costumes,, the display on the ground floor is amazing.

Do not miss!. I thought that after seeing the Tretyakov and Pushkin Museums in Moscow, this would be more of the same. Boy was I wrong. This is a huge museum that covers Russian history and art through the ages, so give yourself time. It takes you from early Christian iconography through the centuries, with paintings from the masters: Repin, Vrubel, Kramskoi, Goncharova, Surikov and more. Names many of us Westerners aren't familiar with, but you'll really appreciate them after you've been to Russia. Don't miss because you think you've "seen it all" already. This was a real high point in my St. Petersburg cultural experience. There's an audioguide that covers the entire museum, which is excellent, and very worth purchasing.
Worth a visit. Take your time going round here - there is plenty of art to see. We don't usally go around art galleries, but this was well worth a visit. Don't forget to buy your Photo permit.

megalomaniac. The Russian museum provides a fascinating and comprehensive overview of Russian art and showcases some truly megalomanica pieces with some bizarre images. So very worthwile to just wander around and be impressed by all those massive paintings whose name you've never heard. The works from Kandinsky and Malevich are wonderful to see here! We felt that information and context on the paintings was missing, our viewing trip would have been more rewarding if we could have put the paintings in context. Is very worthwile to pair your visit to the Hermitage with the Russian Museum.

An excellent museum. The russian museum provides an excellent and comprehensive view of the Russian painting from the 10th to the 20th century. The section dedicated to the Russian avant-guard painters of the early 20th century is great (although it could be larger), while I had the chance to appreciate more the artistic production of the post-war soviet era.
nice exhibitions. they offer very informative temporary and permanent exhibitions. pay attention to works by Paolo Antokolskii , Malyavin,
great value. So much to see. Palace, art, ceramics and a cookery display.Wonderful. Easy to get lost there and it was exhausting but a really good experience

rich collections. There is a lot to this museum and we did not see it all. The collection of Russian art on the main site is very rich and fascinating, and we also saw some lovely folk art - carved wooden furniture and other artefacts and lacquerwork. On a separate site (beside the bridge with takes Nevsky Prospect over the Moyka) we went round the Stroganov Palace, which has marvellous recently restored interiors. There is more on the main site, in the Michailovsky Castle and in the Marble Palace which we did not have time to see.

Fascinating, great collection, but take a compass!. One of the great collections of Russian Art, from the very beginning to the present, including early soviet style porcelain, some of the most technically skilled propaganda pieces you'll ever see. Not only great art but a beautiful building as well. Keep track of where you go however, the building layout itself is a bit confusing and the 'guards' in each room do not speak English. At all.

Museum ladies = BEST. The Russian museum is a strictly chronological trip through Russian history, beginning with (and you MUST begin at the beginning, the museum ladies will allow nothing else) medieval religious iconography through soviet to modern post-Soviet art. A beautiful and wondrous collection. While I wouldn't say, go here over the Hermitage, this is bar none, my second pick of things to see in St. Petersburg. I must see.

An excellant introduction to Russian art. Few museums in western Europe or North America have more than the most cursory collection of Russian art. The State Russian Museum has the best collection in St.Petersburg and one of the two best collections in Russia. I would recommend spending a few hours relatively early in your stay to get a sense of Russian art and culture. Along with many galleries of paintings from various eras there is also displays of folk art, costumes, architectural details from various buildings and the best collection of historical icons in St.Petersburg. The Mikhailovsky Palace in which the collection is located is very handsome.

50/50. The museum itself is great not all of the staff is friendly, cashier especially. Audio guide was helpful though, the lady who sold it to me was very nice gave a full instruction on usage and a few very useful tips on museum visiting.

Only available in Russia!. I visited St Petersburg in September 2013 and had no plan to visit the State Russian Museum!On a private guided tour of the Hermitage Museum our Russian born tour guide/school teacher/art lover made a strong case for visiting the State Russian Museum.Since this museum was close to my hotel I was there at opening time one morning around 10am, paid the 350 Rubles to get in and did my own walk through the countless rooms displaying a wide variety of artwork which you would certainly not find in different parts of the world. All of it is Russian art and craft!It's also not all art I found coins and sculptures and glass and porcelain and furniture from as far back as 250 years.This visit can be done in a much shorter time than visiting the Hermitage Museum as it is quite a bit smaller.There is plenty of restroom access and I did find a nice break at the café for a little sit down during my walking tour.I spent around 2,5 hours here in total and would consider this an excellent museum and worthwhile visit but only after visiting some of the main attractions in SPB.

One of the most outstanding collections of Russian paintings. This museum is a must for those who want to get closer to Russian art and culture. It contains the richest collection of Russian art and covers a wide range of styles and epochs from Rublev and Brullov to Malevich and Petrov-Vodkin.Quite often the different exhibitions are demonstrated there. The visit to this museum is a nice way to understand better Russian history and culture.

A gem!. I came for the Hermitage, but my guide suiggested this museum for Russian art. And it is an absolute gem! All phases of history are covered, in much more detail than the Hermitage. Get yourself a guide though...

Impressive collection of Russian art. We had a 2 hour guided trip. We were moving at a reasonable pace and we maybe saw half of the museum. It is not everyday that you find an art museum that concentrates only on artists from one country. A good concept.

Beautiful and Unique!. I really enjoyed my rather quick tour through this museum, and would have loved to spend a little more time there, even. It was refreshing to see a collection of Russian art, apart from all of the other classical art within St. Petersburg. Granted, there is plenty of classicism within this museum, as well, but visitors are privy to an exploration of art's evolution within Russia, following trends, European imitations, and art demonstrative of peasant life.. Perhaps it's overly common, but my favorite pieces were two portraits of Anna Akhmatova, as well as the Ivan Aivazovsky paintings and a striking sculpture of Catherine the Great.. It's definitely worth a visit while in St. Petersburg. =)

Fantastic museum in a grand building. You need a whole day to visit. you can have a break at the cafe.. Fantastic museum. Start with the Icons and go through Russias history. There are som very famous painter displayed in each room. You can finishe With both modern art and hanycraft.The building itself are a fantastic old castle

10 centuries of Russian Art in a beautiful palace.. The Russian Museum houses one of the best collections of Russian art and craft in the World, from medieval icons to masterpieces by 20th century artists, and includes many landmarks in the history of Russian art, such as Bruillov's 'The Last Day of Pompeii', and Repin's 'The Barge Haulers'. The museum consists of two connected buildings, the Mikhailovsky Palace houses Russian art and sculpture up to 1900, while 20th century art is housed in the Benois Wing.The museum is laid out chronologically, starting with early religious icons in Room 1, and moving on through the centuries. The rooms of 20th century art are particularly interesting, featuring many artists’ work you won’t have seen outside of Russia. The Avant-garde was particularly active in Russia between 1910 and 1930, developing entirely new genres including Cubo-Futurism, Rayonism, Suprematism and Constructivism. The collection has works by every major Russian artist of the 1920’s; Exter, Rodchenko, Filonov, Goncharova, Malevich, Tatlin and many more. From 1932 onwards the only acceptable style of art and literature was Socialist Realism, with its heroic idealised workers, and socialist themes, which are represented in paintings here.In addition to paintings the museum has collections of drawings, graphic design, sculpture, coins, folk art, glass, porcelain, and furniture from the past 300 years, together with contemporary art, installations, video and photography.The museum also has a charming 8 hectare garden, laid out to a 19th century design. The Russian Museum is definitely worth a visit, and is a much more manageable size then the State Hermitage Museum, which can be rather overwhelming. Opening times: 10am-5pm Monday. 10am-6pm Wednesday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday. 1pm till 9pm on Thursday. Closed Tuesdays.The ticket office shuts 30 minutes before the museum closes.Admission: Adults 350 rubles. Students and children150 rubles. Public transport: Nearest Metro, Nevsky Prospekt and Gostiny Dvor.For further information check the museum website.www.rusmuseum.ru

Some wonderful exhibits, great for an afternoon. Although still housing a vast collection the state museum is much more manageable than some of the larger collections in the city. There is a considerable diversity of exhibits including some rather unusual, folk art springs to kind. Entry fee is pretty minimal and there are some great modern collections too, it's all not all Russian nobility although you might want to speed up on the first floor if that's not your bag!
The cafe worths the visit. Amazing building, very nice expositions, very good location - close to all what you will have to see. Had a wonderful break in the cafe.

Be prepared to spend several hours. I believe they have a better collection than the Hermitage. The place is a maze of galleries, and the diversity of the artifacts is just too much for one visit. Plan on making more than one visit

Incredible collection from Icons to Contemporary. It is frankly stupid that the Russian Museum continues to apply a dual pricing system that charges non-citizens more. But that cannot take away from works by Rublev, Serov, Levitan and Kandinsky (to name a few). One of the two greatest collections of Russian art and a beautiful building on Square of the Arts. So unfortunately one has to ignore the discrimination against foreigners, which is offensive and lowers the image of the museum. It's almost sad in a way to tarnish the standing of a great museum for a few more rubles. If the Russian museum wants to earn more money, it should not bother with nonsense like overcharging foreigners, but should go "commercial" like the Louvre and Metropolitan. I must add though that most Russian museums continue to charge foreigners a higher rate. The Hermitage does it. The Pushkin Museum in Moscow does it and the Tretyakov too. It's wrong. I condemn it. But it does nothing to affect my deep love for these wonderful masters. Five stars is much too low a rating for the collection of the State Russian Museum. It is one of the top sites in St Petersburg.

Russian Museum. Great exhibits; superb collection of paintings (including Impressionists whose work seems to be kept in Russia). A truly enjoyable visit. Great excursion for a rainy/cloudy day. 2-3 hours well-spent!

The realy Russian artist!. This I a must see! Just to find out about Russian specifics in art! I liked very corner! Actually, it was not included in our paid tour but we asked for it and they accommodate us. Was great!

some of the best artists you've never heard of. The Hermitage is Western European art collected by the Czars. This museum on the other hand is RUSSIAN art. And lots of it. And much of it very good. We spent a half day and left more because our minds were saturated than because we were sated. There is a nice cafeteria on the ground floor.... and a visit refreshed feet and body before we went back into the fray. A guide can be useful although we went on our own. There is a lot to learn here. The lighting of the paintings is sometimes distracting and I was surprised to see direct sunlight coming through windows and striking paintings. That can't bode well for their longterm health. A person can get very disoriented in the passageways through which you go to check coats, find restrooms, visit gift ships. Pay attention to where you are going.

Almost better than Hermitage. Here the art has room to breath. Some rooms are devoted to a single artist. I was so taken specifically with the paintings of Valentin Serov. The souvenir stands inside the museum do not take credit cards and accept only rubles. Be sure to either have a guide or rent an audio device.

Unlawful pricing discrimination disappoints visitors. I was extremely disappointed to learn the Russian State Museum continues to follow a discriminatory price policy, forcing foreign citizens to pay 40% more than Russians. Not only is this downright hostile to the city's foreign guests, but it is outright illegal under Russian law. Article 62(3) of the Russian Constitution provides, "Foreign nationals and stateless persons shall enjoy in the Russian Federation the rights...of citizens of the Russian Federation, except for cases envisaged by federal law or international treaty..." In other words, for a museum in Russia lawfully to adopt discriminatory pricing against foreigners, a federal law must explicitly authorise this. There is no such law. It is ironic that any museum in Russia, a country with highest number of millionaires and billionaires in the world, would continue to cling to such misconceived discrimination, let alone a museum in St. Petersburg, a city striving to promote itself as a world-class tourist destination. Wake up and smell the coffee, Russian State Museum administrators. This is a blight to the city and its reputation.
Definitely Include. Was not prepared for how good this was - do your homework to decide what you want to see...beautiful building and impressive collection
some wonderful paintings. enjoyed the Russian folk art, and learning about Russian art.nice to be able to leave coats and bags securely as the museum is warm.
very good. this place is great pity you can not take photos but very interesting and plenty to see. takes about an hour but very good

Unbelievable works of art. I've been to many museums in Europe and never really noticed much Russian art. This museum should not be missed. You can buy a 3-day pass that includes a few museums within the Russian Museum. The Russian art we saw was wonderful and made us wonder why we've never heard of many of the Russian artists in the museum.

Well worth a visit. Of course this is not the Hermitage but we found it more enjoyable in some ways. There were less crowds yet the works of art are wonderful.An extensive collection of Icons from all over the country. Paintings of every7 description and period. It is not just paintings there are all kinds of beautiful things on display from lace to wood and bone carvings, ceramic and china. You get a real sense of the diversity of the talent in the country. There is a nice bright coffee shop in the basement. We would highly recommend this first rate museum.

The Only Place for Russian Art. The Hermitage is great, but if you want to see art by Russian artists, this is the place. My husband went with a private guide 9to maximize the experience) but I know I would have enjoyed it even on my own. We spent 3 very wonderful hours, learning about the evolution of Russian art, beginning at the time of the tsars. We were so glad we went.
If you love art this is a must. Amazing and truly inspiring, I don't consider myself an aficionado of art, but I was totally blown away.Well worth investing a day to visit.

Another must visit!. For a extensive overview of Russian art through the ages this museum is a must. The museum is doable in a 1/2 day. There are audio guides and this is also a converted palace so the museum itself is pretty amazing!

Superb Overview of Russian Art. Having just spent 3 days in the State Russian Museum I can only reiterate here what I have been telling everyone - it is without doubt the best lit, displayed and visitor-friendly museum in St Petersburg. Once you have located the Kassa (ticket office) entrance, a rather badly signposted doorway to the right of the main façade, the visit is a total delight. The staff are friendly and knowledgeable, eager to help and obviously proud of their wonderful museum. Arranged chronologically over two floors in adjoining buildings, the 400 000 works in the collection offer an incredible overview of Russian painting and sculpture from the middle ages to the fall of communism.The curator must have an astonishingly difficult job deciding which of the works in the collection to place on show, but what is on display is not crowded onto the walls - each work is sensitively placed and has sufficient "breathing space" - the special exhibition of works by Bruillov from private collections was beautifully hung - and the labeling is clear, at a convenient height, and in English as well as Russian.The guidebooks are well-written and informative, ranging from a pocket companion to a coffee-table tome. The entire premises look clean and well-cared for, and most of the rooms look out on pleasing vistas of park and courtyard.AND - there is a small café in the basement run by very friendly staff with a good selection of beverages, cakes and lunch options, an enormous contrast to the horrors on offer at the Hermitage!A big plus is that tickets are valid for the entire day and multiple entries, so if you need a little while to recover from sensory overload, you can go for a short breather or a snack and go back later for a second dose of this wonderful museum!!Would not have missed this for the world!

A necessary complement to the Hermitage. For those like myself to whom a trip to Russia is not so trivial, it is a unique opportunity to make contact with a huge amount of Russian art of all times. I was deeply impressed by the quality of the works of the times of the "socialist realism". Moreover, the pamphlets, posters and banners of the Soviet period brings a certain nostalgia.

Better than the hermitage I thought. I loved the art in this museum. Russian artists. The works may not always have been as detailed and the hermitage eurpopean art work but the pictures in the russian museum had lots of movement in them and gave a great insight into russian life in the past. I found the art works very moving and impressive.

Russian art at its best. This was not on the 'included' part of our tour to Russia, but it should have been. Some excellent paintings and a really good introduction to Russian artists. And there were not many tourists there.Great place.

All Russian culture. I didn't know anything about Russian arts and in this museum it's possible to have a culture about it. The building is a nice neoclassical building in front of a square in italianskaya ulitza. Inside it's a little bit difficult to understand where is the ticket office, the audio guide desk and the cloak room, but the personnel is almost always very kind (and speaking English). The tour is very well organised in chronological way. A lot of portraits (more or less interesting then the really interesting ones (19th century). Very well organised and very rich collection

brilliant collections. If u ask me what would i choose - Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow or Russian Museam in Saint Petersburg i will defintely recommend you the last. The whole collection is located in a very old buiding and while walking and watching masterpieces you could enjoy the interior as well and dive into old times.My recommends to find time to stand near Aivazoskiy's paintings. His manner of painting marine sceneries is something. Go to see Kuingee's "Moon light over the Dneper" - a mysterious one. "last night of Pompeas" by Brulov is thrilling.

Russian art through the centuries. Allow plenty of time for this one. Here one kind find Russian art from religious icons dating back to the 11th century to modern art of today and everything in between. Wonderful experience.

Don't Overlook This Excellent Museum. The Hermitage is far larger and has much better known works but we found the Russian Museum's work by Russian born artists to be very attractive and it is far easier to manage than the Hermitage. The collection ranges from ancient icons and folk art through the 18th and 19th century through Russia's revolutionary and Soviet periods.

Another great Museum here in St.P. Another fantastic art museum here in the city. While not as large as the Heritage, it is still full of lots of great works of art. Great for a rainy or cold day here in the city.

Another good museum. While the Hermitage impresses with wealth, incredible beautiful interiors and highly esteemed collections, the Russian State Museum is more normal... This is a place where without any stirring you can learn a lot about Russian national art. There are presented different expositions and suppose everyone can find something interesting to his taste.
Basement maze. Did a too quick and unguided visit here - the basement with toilets tickets etc is a bit of a maze, but lots of good Russian art above

Better than the hermitage. Ok, so in terms of content that is clearly not true. But as a visitor I felt I got a better feel for Russia and the national identity and heritage than from the Hermitage which is simply huge and grand and not full of Russian art or artifacts to the same extent. Ideally go to both. Several times.

A very good museum. I did not know much about russian modern art and this museum is perhaps one of the best places I have been to learn a bit about it. And at the same time I found the staff much more friendy than in the Hermitage.
Well worth visiting. I knew nothing about Russian Art - but it is well worth visiting if only to put the artists on the map - they ought to be far more widely known

Time well spent, very pleased the hermitage was closed.. I spent 3 nights in Russia which really isn't enough time to see everything. I had wanted to go back through the hermitage museum on my own as I felt rushed with my husband. On Monday (our last day) we decided to split up and visit different attractions however when I got to he hermitage it was closed. I decided to head to the Russian museum and was very pleased I did. The art is more modern and contemporary steering away from the biblical depictions and naked cherubs. I think there really is something for everyone's tastes there and you could go about at a leisurely pace without the crowds. So many great Russian artists I had never heard of, thank goodness the hermitage was closed!
