Go for the Folk Art. We really liked the Tretykov in Moscow which also showcases Russian art, but we didn't fall in love with this museum. We love Russian icons and the State Russian Museum has very few, especially compared to the Tretykov or Novgorod. On a more positive note, the folk art was amazing. If I were to do it again, I would start with the folk art and skip many of the other areas. The folk art collection is varied and extensive and gorgeous.

If you don't like the crowds at the Hermitage.... Try the Russian Museum. There are some really positive aspects to visting the Russian Museum. It is usually less crowded than the Hermitage and you are able to view the collection at closer views. The collection here is less overwhelming than at the hermitage, and the collection gives the viewer a better picture of Russian life. Especially go to this museum if you are a fan of the Russian rurals. The gift store in the museum is also worth mentioning. The have a good selection of souvenirs for a better price than other museums. When I was there I purchased some beautiful scarves for a really good price.

not as interesting for non russians. especially when you already visit the "heavy duty" hermitage, this might just be one museum too many if you're not russian and don't have a feeling for what they call "must see"

A hidden jewel. We went here because it was raining and how lucky that turned out to be! There was a special exhibition of the work of Alexander Golovin. He was a painter and set designer. Worth the entrance money on its own.
This is big. This is worth seeing but it is a lot of walking and climbing stairs. Nothing else like it and worth the 3-4hr it takes.

The Hermitage. This world class museum and Winter Palace are a must see if one is to call themselves a world traveler. The treasure it is and the treasures it holds within should be permanently and lovingly preserved for the world to view.

Loved the Russian Museum. Went to the Russian Museum a day after the Hermitage. It was much quieter and so more enjoyable, with remarkable art collection that has not been as popularized as others (at least for non-Russians!). We were fortunate to have a Russian friend point out his favourite items. Ranges from fine old paintings to Soviet era to lacquer boxes, carvings, pottery, and much more. Don't miss it.

A very attractive, airy, and uncrowded gallery - rather a hidden gem.. Just off Nevsky Prospect (next to the Church of Spilled Blood), this large art gallery is a little off the beaten track, off the major tourist radar, and is consequently much quieter (few coach parties with pushy guides).It focuses on home-grown Russian art, with a large collection of works from over 500 years of their history, with paintings, sculpture, and ceramics from the classical era, Soviet period, and modern art.Large, light, and airy rooms make it a pleasant place to spend time.

Great collection of the Russian art. The exposition covers a period of one thousand years, from Andrei Rublev to the modern art. Amazing collection of 19th century paintings represents all great names. Strongly recommended.

Interesting collection of Russian art. Every time I visit Russian museum I find something new for me. I know very well its old collection of Rerih, Shishkin, Vasnetsov, Repin, etc. and I admire it. Last visit I knew the contemporaneous art collection and was very impressed.

Don't miss this gem of a museum. Everyone visiting St Petersburg goes to the Hermitage, and rightly so. But you won't see any Russian painting there, because all those paintings are in this museum. We entered through the Benois wing right by the Church of the Spilled Blood and loved the exhibition of modern Russian painting there. Then we went into the Mikhailovsky Palace for earlier Russian paintings and the amazing architecture. It was like visiting the Tate Britain and Modern in one go. Not to be missed. All of us thought this was as well worth visiting as the Hermitage.

Fine collection of 19th and 20th century Russian Art. Everybody rushes to see the Hermitage and given it can take so long to see everything there, tend to give this a miss. Mistake. This is a fantastic collection of Russian Art with a particularly fine section covering the last 200 years. Just round the corner from the Church on the Spilled Blood so you can do the 2 sights on the same day.

I love this place. Very nice museum which i love to come. Huge collection of Russian artists from 14th century to nowadays, i.e. from Russian icons till contemporary art. Not as huge as Hermitage, convenient location in the very centre of the city. Located in the former Great Price Mikhail palace that is another beautiful palace itself in the ‘gold ring’ of many St.Petersburg palaces.
Not crowded and great overview of Russia. Don't miss this opportunity to leisurely get an introduction to Russia and its art. Few tourist, mostly Russians strolling through this museum.
Dont miss it. You may overlook it because of the grandeur of Hermitage, but I would strongly recommend to devote almost as much time for this museum. Breathtaking collections.

A museum the city can be truly proud of.. First class art and sculpture in a fabulous setting. My wife loved the folk art and I loved the simplicity of a painting called the queue and the sadness of seeing the painting of Peter the Great on his deathbed. One room is from the original palace and the wooden floor work is stunning together with the splendour within the room. Take time to enjoy the superb ceiling work. Admission of 350 roubles is a bargain and allow a good 3 hours if you want to do it justice. A plea on behalf of my wife is to offer more facilities for the ladies as the queues were too long and there were just not enough within the building.
art!!!!!!. what a fabulous museum.around the corner from our hotel.a jewel.....art that you don' see in many other places

Quieter than the Hermitage. The Russian Museum has more art dedicated to Russian painters/sculptors than the nearby Hermitage museum and is a lot smaller so allows you to amble around without the pressure of the crowds. I'd highly recommend Lonely Planet's St Petersburg guide as it details all of the rooms and contents which helps as very little is labelled in detail on the walls. There are more examples of early Russian icon art than the Hermitage and given that the rooms are still very large, you can take your time and look at each piece without being disturbed. There is a natural flow to the rooms that lead you from one section to the next so no worries about being lost. The central grand staircase is a good place to orientate yourself. The cloakrooms however are truly baffling and we laughed when we couldn't find the right desk, going around in circles for 10 minutes down identical corridors. There is no cafe here so bring a drink and the last 2 hours of the day are an ideal time to visit. The schools have left and tourists are back on their coaches so you can have the place more or less to yourself on a weekday. It's also very hot inside even when the heating is off and summer hasn't warmed up yet. Dress light and with practical shoes as there isn't any seating we could find.

A favorite museum. I love the Hermitage, but this is where the Russian art is. Also in a former palace, the museum is chock a block full of beautiful portraits, landscapes and art from icons to contemporary.
Not to missed. One of the biggest Russian art collection. Extremely pleasant to visit. Make sure to have the audio guide. No waiting lignes

My favorite museum in Petersburg. So many of Petersburg's many treasures are from or directly inspired by Western Europe. This museum emphasizes Russian artists instead, and is both educational and well as a treat for the eyes to see so many excellent and original pieces and styles of art.

Interesting thematic museum. This was a great museum to visit. We came as part of a tour, and only spent about a bit more than an hour there (we didn't get to the exhibits of more recent material), but the museum was well-organized sequentially, as you got a history of Russian art simply by going from room to room. I did like the Hermitage more for the chance to visit rooms that were once part of a palace, and the Hermitage did have great collections of, e.g., Impressionist paintings, but I found the Russian museum more informative about Russia's own art.

Beautiful Galleries. The Russian Museum is an excellent place to see examples of Russian art through the ages. In addition there are exhibits of armory and other art forms. . Some of the ancient Iconic painting such as the Madonna and child are exceptional. When you are exhausted from walking and looking at the art work go across the street from the main entrance and sit for awhile in a lovely park and people watch.

If you like Russian art and iconography, go here. They have "The Wave" and many ancient icons and wooden items taken from ancient churches, it's something I really enjoyed. Ignore the guys walking around with loaded Kalishnakovs.

Great collection of Russian artworks. The place is less popular than others but we found it worth a visit to see a great collection. For those art lovers, you will appreciate and like the russian art works. Compare to hermitage this place is much less crowded. It is next to the spilled blood church, better go on the same day. We have more pix to share at https://picasaweb.google.com/100092841543065224921/StPetersburgRussia2013

great. What a lovely surprise. A large and spacious museum and not overcrowded. A must if you are interested in Russian art. An excellent selection of 19th and 20th century Russian art. not to be missed

Hermitage better. Hermitage covers almost everything. If you have more time and want to understand more Russian art then worthwhile going. It is well organized and tickets cost 350 rubbles. It is the lane to hotel the Europe. The shops inside the museum are reasonable and nice.

Definitely Worth a Visit. I am not a fan or art, nor will I ever be. But I always visit art galleries when I travel because of the vast historical significance that they typically hold. The State Russian Museum was a hidden gem. There was a lot of wonderful art to see here with many great pieces. I really liked that it focuses on Russian art and its history. Not a must see, but worth it for art fans and if you have some time in the city.
not to be missed. 4 rooms dedicated to beautiful icons and Natalia at the ground floor + Natalia Goronchova painting in the Benois aisle
Okay but Not a Must-see. Extensive collection of works by Russian artists, but we thought the Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow had a better collection more attractively displayed.

Fabulous Collection. The State Russian Museum provides a superb overview of Russian Art. Without a deep or thorough education in art history, I was unfamiliar with many of the artists, Quickly getting past this, I thought the selected art works were uniformly superior in quality and present the parallel courses and divergences between Western European art movements and Russian artists and the unique Russian schools. After having spent two days at the Hermitage, I really enjoyed the fact that this museum was uncrowded and the art was accessible. BTW, the paintings of Kandinsky and Chagall were out on loan according to a docent.The folk art collection is not to be missed. To be crass, the selected pieces of folk art are exactly what you hope to find while shopping for souvenirs but never find!

Might not be the most glamorous, but the collection is worth seeing!. This museum deserves more accolades than it gets. The collection of Russian art is absolutely amazing. If you have time, be sure to stop by. Definitely worth a visit!
A MUST See. This museum is often overshadowed by the Hermitage but is also a fabulous to experience and should not be missed. Featuring a wide range of Russian art one can spen

Russian Art Treat. It was my first time at the State Russian Museum and I really enjoyed it! I'm not much into art in general but this museum had some really interesting works, especially those of Aivazowski. The museum is a nice size, not too large and you can easily see everything in 2-3 hours. They have pretty good toilet and cloakroom facilities. Only downside was that you aren't allowed to drink any water as you go around (unless you do it sneakily!). In some of the rooms it was quite stuffy and hot.

Wonderful collection. If interested in Russian painting, don't miss the large collection of Repin works. As for landscapes, Shishkin is amazing. Also worth the visit is the building, in large part due to Carlo Rossi, the Italian architect.

Fabulous art. What a brilliant collection of paintings. And their Rembrandt's were magnificent. I always though that Rembrandt painted small pictures - not so, they have some very large canvases painted by him. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit but not essential. Lost of other palaces in St Petersburg are as grand or ornate. Most interesting for us were Peter the Great's death mask and portrait on his death bed, as well as portraits of the rest of the royal family. You can see the resemblances, and his death mask makes you feel as if you are meeting Peter himself!

So you don't think you'd be interested in Russian Art?. 4 hours was not enough time to savor all that is here...do not miss the Repin paintings! The early Russian works are equally interesting and the hall with the largest paintings we've ever seen is overwhelming...Do not miss the cases in the rooms under velvet covers to see exquisite paper works...

Russian art by Russian artists. Small but excellent collection of Russian religious art, in addition to the usual portraits. These portraits are all by Russian artists however. A short walk from the Church of the Spilled Blood or Nevsky Prospekt. Good way to pass a few hours. You can take photos of the exhibits but cannot use the flash.

Art, Art, Art. Not to be missed. The only problem is that at the end of the visit you are so tired you don´t have energy enough to enjoy all the precious jewels you have seen. The best would be to go there more than once if possible.

Good but not as impressive as the Hermitage. After navigating through the Hermitage, one of the highlights here for me was the absence of tour groups and the relative peace and quiet. That said the art collection here is not as extensive or impressive.Entrance is 350 rbls and we spent 2 hours here enjoying the art. You could easily spend more.Our favourite section was in the Benois gallery, which had a great collection of modern 20th century art, housed in a beautifully light and airy space.I'd also highly recommend finding a map, to get the most out of this building. Upstairs is easy to navigate, however downstairs there are entire wings of the museum, either hidden round dark corners or down small staircases!

Closed. Such a pitty, this museum was specially recommended to us, but when we found it after a long walk, it turned out to be closed on Tuesdays! Didn't have the time to go on another day. So, we'll have to visit St. Petersburg again;-)....

My Favorite. Our favorite museum experience in SPB. The museum is a former palace and worth touring on its own. Combined w the incredible Russian art from all periods go history just can not be beat. For us, better than the Hermitage. Call us heathen!

Blew me away. Extremely interesting museum, packed full of top notch russian art, which you had little idea about. Take your time and soak up the russian experience reflected in un-usual scenes and periods in time. Probably the next best sight to take in after the Hermitage.
give yourself a day!. What a treat - a feast of russian art. There is alot of it and have never heard of most of the artists - but really enjoyed every room. the Kandinsky's are on tour this year!

A big disappointment. Dedicated the same amount of time to it as the Hermitage and was frankly disappointed. Not in the same league of cultural significance but also, didn't find it as pleasant to walk the halls. Have previously read reviews of extremely unfriendly service - all those were confirmed. So basically, all in all, didn't really enjoy being continually shouted at by the "babushkas" for seemingly not doing anything wrong.

Incredibly Interesting. Really enjoyed all the exhibits here, the folk art was amazing. Take a look out in the external wings as they are really worth a look - here you will find pottery, clothing, building materials, lace etc. We spent a fascinating afternoon here.

To discover Russia. This was one of my favorite museum as it was trully unique, containing Russian work of art, which I am not very familiar with, as well as beautiful folk craft. Truly eye opening on the rich heritage of Russian art and craft.

Remarkable. The museum's collection includes over 400,000 artworks covering the complete history of Russian art, from 11-th century icons to works by contemporary artists. For someone wanting to understand Russian culture and history, I would recommend a visit to the Russian Museum. It’s not crowded like the Hermitage, but has a plenty to offer.

Neatly organized. Excellent collections, I loved the portraits and other depictions of Russian monarchs. The buildings itself are very interesting and beautiful, even though not as distracting as richly decorated Hermitage. Even though I would heartilly recommend even here to look both to the ground and ceiling.

Enjoyable, Interesting. We went with a toddler in a baby carrier, who drew our attention to the ceilings of the main building of the museum (I believe there are 5 buildings). Some truly fun and interesting ceiling designs on the top floor. We enjoyed the primer on Russian art.

Beautiful collection and special exhibit. We enjoyed this collection very much, especially the special exhibit in one of the wings. All russian art, but the exhibit comprised artists from the late 1800's to the present. The paintings were beautiful, and I have a new appreciation for Russian artists.

Enjoy the history and culture of Russian through visual art and craft. One of my greatest pleasures when travelling is visiting the local museums. While it is sometimes expedient to have a guide point out some of the highlights of a particular venue, I generally find it more satisfying to follow my interests and wander at my own pace. My problem with many of the museums/galleries we visited while in Russia was the lack of signage in English [or any other language, for that matter.] So I was happy to read that the Russian Museum in St. Petersburg provided a printed guide and wall signs in English. And what a wonderful collection of Russian art is displayed within the walls of the Mikhaylovsky Palace! The building alone is worth a visit with its grand staircases and statuary. The collection is well organized in chronological order with the earliest items dating back to the 12th century and ending with a large section devoted to folk art. This was the highlight of the museum for me – colourful toys of wood and porcelain, regional clothing, table ware, and of course, the originals of the lacquered spoons that so many people buy as souvenirs. It was a perfect way to spend a rainy afternoon -- learning more about the history and culture of Russia and surprise – when we left the museum, the sun was shining and we took another walk along the canals.
Not as interesting as the rest. Went there for 3 hours that I can't really recall very well now that I've left - yes, there's some good stuff here but I was more impressed by other St Pete landmarks
Amazing collection of folk art. I loved the folk art displays - lots of lace, woodworking, fabric design. Look out for the mice burying the cat - a wooden toy.
Surprise dinner!. The guided tour was very educational, and the dinner accompanied by a string quartet was incredible!

Beauty. The first four rooms with icons and old russian art are pure beauty. If you're medieval geek do not hesitate to visit this place. There's of course a lot of other great things to see. For me it was for example Ivan Shishkin's landscapes or Repin's masterpieces

Russian Museum St. Petersburg.. We went on a Sunday morning before the crowds. On a Sunday it gets very busy with families and school groups ( in winter at least). I am not overly keen on Modern Russian art but the old exhibits were very good as were some of the old icons, well worth the visit. allow several hours.

Do not miss it. I was not familiar with Russian artists so this was a first experience. I was truly impressive; the collection was comprehensive and representative of Russian art through the ages. I was so glad that I did not miss it.

Well presented and lots to see. This museum only shows Russian art and artefacts, rather than the Hermitage, which is world-wide exhibits. However, it was a fascinating study of the Russian heritage and past.

Unexpected. I never new much about Russian paintings until I visited this one. The collection is marvelous!!! I know that this tour is not considered to be the most popular - but after visiting this museum I simply can not understand why. My guide added a lot to this experience explaining about the paintings and the artists and the Russian History behind some of the paintings. I was not sure about taking this tour at first and I am so happy I finally decided to go!!!
better than the Hermitage!. This is a great place to see Russian art from a variety of eras. (Socialist Realism, Russian Masters, etc). For me, it was more interesting that the Hermitage!
A must see. You should definitely visit this place during your stay in the city! There you can find many masterpieces from Russian visual art, audio guides in many different languages are available.
Do not miss this museum. Wonderful collection of Russian art which allows you to understand so much about Russia and the aesthetic that shapes the people. Do not miss the Benois wing.

Not quite like the Hermitage. Doesn't have the same iconic appeal and I found the place a little bit harder to navigate around in terms of finding some specific pieces that I was looking for. Staff spoke only very basic English and I ran into a problem at the cloakroom which thankfully was rectified after a lot of stress

Amazing Collection. I like to visit this museum every time I am in St Petersburg. It is very comprehensive, including fine and applied arts, and they have also got a marvelous collection of contemporary Russian art. Their temporary exhibitions are usually excellent. The paintings by Repin are a must as well as their icon paintings. I particularly like the folk art, too, and their works from the revolutionary period. There are kiosks scattered throughout the museum which sell some very good material, some in English.

Guided tour a must for real experience. I highly recommend to buy a guided tour to get the max info and enjoyment out of the visit. It is a very large collection with lots of history and interesting facts attached which your tour guide will share with you. Very well worth the money spent on guided tour.
Interesting museum. Interesting museum and is not as crowded as The Hermitage Museum. Information is also provided in English
Better than Hermittage. It was very interesting to visit this museum. A lot of paintings and very nice exhibitions. It is definitely Worth spending a few times in that museum! Enjoy

Into to Russian art. Scored free tickets otherwise I wouldn't have bothered to visit yet another museum but it was a great introduction to Russian art. The palace it's hoped in is worth seeing as well.

The real gem of the city!. My favourite museum in St.Petersburg.
Its collection of the Russian icons is unique in the world. Very educative and heartrending.
Vrubel and Aivasovskiy masterpieces are unforgettable and very impressive.
The Russian painting of the early 20 century sometimes reaches the height of the European mpressionism, post-impressionism and analitycal abstractionism. (See Petrov-Vodkin, Filonov, Golovin)
Entrance fee -200rub. It's a MUST!

The Best of Russian Fine Arts. The Main Building, the splendid Mikhailovsky Palace houses the world's largest collection of russian art from icons to 20th century paintings. The museum is well organised and well kept. Extremely interesting.
Wonder Russian works of art. Buy the combine ticket to get into 3 other venues which are all within walking distance and wonderful building and art works. Go early to avoid the tour groups.

Poor service in the central museum of St. Petersburg. We visited the museum with my wife this weekend and almost regretted. The place is marked "Tripadvisor suggested". Well, I propose foreigners to visit Ethnographic museum situated 1 minute walk nearby. It was disagreeably even for me as a citizen to confront this soviet-type service:- long awkward labyrinth from the cash office to the cloakroom: ending which you are already tired :)- boorishness of the cloakroom staff: you can not carry big luggage and backpacks with you so you are asked to leave it in cloakroom, nevertheless the staff says they take only not valuable things; I received "This is your problem" when I politely explained how inconvenient it is to visit museum with my notebook and camera with me; cashier was talking on the phone all time- poor signing within the halls, disturbing window lights when examining the exhibits, rude staff (not all but in general)The exhibits were interesting. I also liked the idea with QR codes which shows you info on the work. Regretfully it only works with local soft which is aweful.Nevertheless management shows a lack of interest to its clients. Frankly speaking you go to museum to see something interesting and receive a service. This place provides none and you go mad in the beginning. I propose RM management to carefully inspect all elements of the modern museum service and implement it quickly - it is a shame to propose such service nowadays.

The place to see Russian Art. This museum houses a wonderful collection of Russian art and artifacts. The Marble Palace is also under this heading, but be careful about opening and closing times. We went according to the brochure we obtained at the headquarters of the Russian Museum itself, only to be told that the Marble Palace was not open when we arrived.

A must in St.Pete. This museum needs 2 days to really see how fantastic collection it is.You can also do photography there.They also have good restaurant and there are less crowds than in Hermitage.you can also get a better understanding of Russia.I can direct you to pleasant Russian guide who made our visit well worth it.The Russian visa is expensive and nightmare.Latest "agreement " benefits the Russian site but not US.ffiber41@gmail.com

Russian Folk Art. We went there just for the folk art, and were not disappointed. A good display of woven, embroidered and wooden art forms were quite well displayed. Close to the Spilled Blood Church, and in easy walking distance to Nevsky Prospekt.

My favorite museum in St Petersburg!. Although it is smaller and less opulent than the Hermitage this is a truly Russian museum unlike the Hermitage. I loved the focus on Russian art and history and there are some truly special paintings and icons in this museum. We even watched a movie clip of the palace guards firing on the demonstrators on Bloody Sunday in the Palace Square! It was truly jaw dropping. Don’t miss this little gem! Plus it has a fabulous cafe with great ambiance and food (much better than the Hermitage cafe!) Spend several hours here.

Fabulous!. I'm not a big fan of art museums, but the State Russian Museum was fantastic. I went twice; once by myself and back again with my wife. Toured for over four hours each visit. Audio guide is very good. Don't get mesmerized by the amazing art and forget to look at the Rossi designed Mikhaylovskiy palace. A toss up with the Hermitage for me. Look for the guy texting in Repin's "Barge-Haulers on the Volga".
Don't Miss this one. The Hermitage is the culture draw, but the Russian Museum exposes the depth and breadth of Russian culture. I always visit here and the Marble Palace first, then the Hermitage.

A Hidden Gem. I had never heard of this museum before I visited St Petersburg as it is somewhat dwarfed by it's famous counterpart the Hermitage. The museum is located close to the Church of the Spilled Blood, there are also some nice cafe's close where you can have a good lunch. You can easily vist both and have a spot of lunch all in a day.As the museum is not so well known it is not that busy and much more easier to gain entry than the Hermitage. We turned up at 11am and got in within 2 minutes!Once inside you are rewarded with a museum that focuses solely on Russian art over the centuries including more recent modern art.We highly recommend this museum.

Lots to see. This is a vast museum. I really liked the art being displayed in a chronological order. That made It easy to see how art styles developed in Russia. How most of the art was amassed is a rather sad story.
Another stunning building. Different to the Hermitage less grand but still very interesting displays of ethnic crafts alongside the huge historical paintings.

Good contrast to the Hermitage. The Hermitage is brilliant but not very Russian. This in contrast is just Russian art so arguably tells you more about the country than the Hermitage. The audio guide adds to the enjoyment enormously.

The most important museum to see in the city for art lovers. The museum is nicely located in the surrounding of the other monuments. My advice is to go to the museum from the very first hour since it is opened. The old building still has problems with ventilation and after the night the air is better inside. You need any way to spend there at least two hours just to walk around the museum. You will be tired, especially if you will pay attention to the art and spend there 3-4 hours. The park behind the museum is connected to the Summer Park - another attraction. It is rather good, especially after recent restorations. It may be very nice to walk through these parks after the museum. Unfortunately it is the advise only to summer time visitors - winter time in SPb the light day is very short.

Russian Museum. There is a wonderful show right now -unknown artist who painted portraits of the Tsarist families. the who museum is so historical. Here, as in most places directions for how to get about are vague.

Don't miss this. This museum houses Russian artists from about the 15th century to the end of the 20th/beginning of the 21st. Other than Chagall and Kandinsky, these are artists we do not see in the West.

Pre Plan. As its been calulated that it would take you 17 years to view all the exhibits, its perhaps best if you identified the rooms where your particular interests lie before the visit . Independent guides appear to have more flexibility in this regard.
Unique opportunity. Wonderful collection from all periods . The big canvases are breathtaking . A good way to learn about Russian history and art . Lovely settings and arrangement

Wonderful experience, great Russian art unknown to us in the west. Easy museum entry unlike the Hermitage. Never a line at the door. Fabulous collection of Russian Art not seen in the west. About 10 pieces by Malevich and 3 pieces by Kandinsky. Plus a great collection of other Russian modernists. Collection ranges from 20th century back to the 15th century. Also a lot of early furniture. You must have cash to purchase in the museum bookstores. I visited this museum 4 times in a week. Postcards of artwork very inexpensive (50 cents per card). This mueum is next door to the Sacred Blood Russian Orthodox church.

Great!. Another vast palace filled with art. I was most interested in the historic paintings and the modern art. One paining of people hauling a boat on the Volga river was very powerful, evoking the hard work of the poor people.

Russki Muzei. Venetsianov, Brulov, Repin, Surikov, Serov, Levitan, Malevitch, Rerikh... you name it. Russian art is worth another day, spent in museum. Constant rain outside makes this option even more reasonable.
Russian Treasures. The highlights of Russian treasures are well presented in the displays here. Missed the special collection of jewels but it's worth visiting to get a view of history and grandeur.
Deservs a visit. Nice museum, good art collections (if you want to see Russian painters). I'd certainly recommend. Plus, it's located in a beautiful spot of the city.
Fabulous Russian art. Less crowded than the Hermitage. Some very nice Russian paintings by Shishkin, Repin and Aivazovsky. Good museum shops.

A nice surprise!. Beautiful Russian art. It is well displayed. Audioguides are good although you may not need them. Just enjoy the paintings! Wonderful art from the 20th century is displayed at the end. Do not miss it!

Great collection of Russian art. A number of famous original paintings are located in this museum, definitely second museum to visit in St Petersburg after Hermitage. To see main pieces of art allocate couple of hours, a building itself is quite beautiful as most palaces of that era.

Great Collections of art. On the day when we arrived, we could pay double the price of one ticket and see 4 museums. The museums were the Marble Palace, Stroganoff Palace, Mikailovsky Palace and the Russian Museum. We only saw the latter three.Stroganoff Palace's interior was awesome. No photos allowed.One must always check in the coats when they arrive. Each of the entrances is guarded.Not many of the people in the museum speak English, so don't expect to be understood. I made the mistake of saying good day in Russian, and the woman thought I spoke russian and she spoke no English, so that was a bit difficult.All of the museums that we visited were worth the price of admission.

Very interesting. This museum is in a huge building but entered by a small side door which then leads you through low tunnel like corridors in a maze until you find yourself at the ticket office. then you have to retrace your steps back through these "tunnels" and finally after several old ladies (the guides sitting at every corner) have pointed you in the right direction, you go up to the museum. After the Hermitage it is an altogether more ccessible museum and well worth visiting for some fabulous art and statues.
Development of Russian art. We expected great art, but found it a historical presentation of the development of Russian art. Art arranged chronilogically.
worth your time. this museum is not on the usual tours, but with a good guide you will be treated to Russian art starting with special icons
best russian painters. Really good collection of best Russian painters, starting from Rublov and a lot of others, Shishkin, Aivazovski, nearly all famouse paintings are ther

Baltic Cruise July 2012. Just back for a memorable Baltic cruise. We went on the Royal Carribean Jewel fo the Seas. We sailed from Harwich and this was brilliant no luggage restrictions and dragging cases round. We went to Denmark, Finland, Sweden Tallin and Russia. We have never been on a cruise before and were not sure we would enjoy it. We are both in our early 50s and had always considered cruise for retired people, we were so wrong. The ship was a fantastic experience and the itinery was amazing waking up each day in a new place. We cannot fault the ship on cleaniness and excellent service. Also if you don't like dressing for dinner you don't have to there are casual dinning rooms that serve excellent food with lots of choice and you can eat any time the only draw back is the cost of drinks at the bar and 15% service charge. The sunsets are amazing and very romantic, we have some great photographs and wonderful memories. I would recommend a cruise for any age and you will not be dissapointed. Its like staying in a 5* hotel that takes you to so many different countries, you even forget your on a ship until you go on deck. You meet lots of people from all over the world and there is always a quiet place to sit and read your book if you have never tried a cruise I recommend you do.

a great surprise. This is the best museum in town and one of the best I've ever seen.It gives the oportunity to discover great russian painters, almost unknown to the most people of west Europe.The museum is small, but a very beautiful jewel.And the Mikhailkovsky gardens in front of the museum are so romantic and beautiful.

NOT TO BE MISSED. The top museum of Art in St Pertsburg! If you have time for only one museum leave out Hermitage and come here!! The Russian school of Paintings is something unbeliavable.!! Less known to the west because of the long Soviet period but here you come face to face with the great names such as :Repin , Kuindji, Aivasovsky, Vrubel etc

Russian Museum was wonderful!. Following the advice of all of my guidebooks, I went to see the Russian art collection in the Russian Museum and it was WONDERFUL! The collection was wide-ranging -- including Russian Orthodox Church icons, portraits and furnishings of Russian monarchy, 18th and 19th century Russian art, porcelain and majolica, lace and other fabrics, lacquer boxes, even historical Russian housing architecture and more. Because I went in the afternoon and was tired when I entered, I only did the Michaelovsky Castle, which is huge. I did splurge on the English audiotape guide which was worth the extra $350.00 rubles since there was very little text --Russian or English -- accompanying the exhibits. Because I was tired, I told myself I'd only stay an hour or so, and didn't expect to get my money's worth for the $350.00 rubles admission. But the exhibits kept changing and were so varied and reflected things I'd actually seen in the country (e.g., lacquer boxes) that I just kept walking --for 3-4 hours. That's what a great museum should do -- grab your attention and hold on for dear life. The Russian Museum was GREAT!

Worth a visit to see excellent Russian Art. A good collection of Russian Art covering many periods. Your chance to see what was and is going on. The audio-guide is very good and helps to make sure you really enjoy the visit.

I loved this museum. The day I went the museum was quiet. It has a very intimate feel with stunning art. I liked the variety of art they showed as well as the building. I also earned about several Russian artists I had never seen. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here and highly recommend it.
Worth a visit. All the Russian classics are here, if you have time, a definite must-see. Now the Marble Palace is also part of the Russian Museum

Trip into the ART OF PAINTINGS. My last time I visited this palace of Art in 1984. This is amazing place, collections, etc...
The pleasure begins with the first thought that you are going to visit this Museum.
Best of the best - Polenov Hall, Repin. I can spend hours and hours ....

Very good and well organized place. Big, interesting and beautiful works. Simple and well organized. Hermitage should learn from them! Staff was friendly and helpfull, what a delight to be able to get the answers to our questions without being told off every time! We really enjoyed this museum.

Felt this was unnecessary after the Hermitage. From the perspective of the casual art goer, the State museum was not at all a highlight of St. Petersburg. I was expecting something almost as exceptional as the Hermitage after seeing the raves here, but think you must be a bit more in the know about Russian art than we are to really love this. At $10 each, I think you can skip it if you only have a couple days in the city and are not particularly into Russian art. You will be delighted at the Hermitage even if you know nothing about art, would suggest you spend a few extra hours there instead of going here.

A Must to See.. If you feel that the Hermitage is a wondrous display then you must see the Russian artists in this Museum. The exhibitions are tastefully and movingly displayed and moved me to tears.Allow time to explore the Museum - you will not be disappointed and the staff are very friendly.

A wealth of wonderful art. Very interesting indeed, so much to see and enjoy, however the same thing applies about lining up outside for ages whilst groups took priority. This I believe should be taken care of!
Informative Displays, though not all had English translations. Lots to see, in depth look at the different cultures that make up Russia. Features many costumes, daily life artifacts, crafts, etc.
Russian applied arts must be seen. The best russian applied arts collection collected in this museum - we had 3 full hours of diving in the past of Russian culture.

Must see. If you want to get to know Russia better do not miss State Russian Museum! You can find the painting by famous Russian artist as Repin, Levitan, Bryullov, Aivazovsky, Shishkin, Polenov ext. It is grate museum with a special atmosphere and Russian soul.
Small and easy to navigate. Holds works worth seeing. Only takes an hour to see the entire museum. In a very touristy area, beware of large buses!
Wow!!!!. Faberges,jewels and artifacts galore to help you understand the culture of a people. Not to be missed.
Russian Art at its best. Learn more about Russias Christian heritage at this beautiful museum.

All Russian works of art but some Surprises!. I really wasn't interested in most of the portraits, sculpture of Russian historical figures and landscapes. Some interesting historical scenes.My surprise was that the architectural elements of the rooms were exquisite, one - the empire room - was full of original empire furniture and just incredible. The other was the three very large Victorian era paintings of incredible beauty by Russian artist and I hope I can attach two to my review, the file may be to large.

fabulous. Need to spend more time here, one needs 3 hours at least, the gardens in front are neatly laid out.The courtyard and gardens in front give glimpses of the spires and coloured domes of the Church of the Spilled Blood in the background.

it is quite nice. they have quite a collection, and watching the people that work there, dozing off is quite good fun - picture retired age people, they are well tired and bored... lots of items to see..takes about 3 hours to go through.
State Russian Museum. This is an absolute MUST SEE! Overwhelmed by those majestic paintings! Please buy the book!

Fantastic Museaum better Art than the Hermitage. this was probably the highlight of the trip, a museum that isn't crowded and has some excellent pieces in. it is near the church of the spilled blood so do both the buildings together. The cafe is ok but not great, forget the coffee and buy water

Must visit for Russian art lovers!. This is a must visit place for Russian art lovers. One will find mostly paintings of popular Russian artists here including impressionist painters like Konstantin Korovin, Vasily Polenov and others. For us, 3 hours is enough for this museum.

Better than Hermitage for Russian Art. If you want to see real Russian art go to the State Russian Museum and skip the Hermitage. We saw both and all four of us preferred the State Russian Museum for the Russian icon art and 19th - 20th cent Russian artist and Russian content art. We wanted to see Russian art while in Russia and it was excellent. We have been to other great European art museums and the content in the Russian Museum was unique vs the Hermitage which was same "European master art" as in other museums. This was an add on to a busy schedule and we had app 1 hr with our guide. We were in St Petersburg via a cruise ship for 2 days touring with Denrus in a 4 person group.
Russian Museum. Fine collection particularly of 19th century Russian art. Some ENORMOUS paintings
Russian art. We found a great display of Russian Art here. We did not allow enough time as it is far bigger than we thought.

Blown away by the quality of art here!. I learned so much about Russia here. And some of the canvasses, like Ivan Aivazovsky's "The Wave," literally feel like you are swept away along with the ship-- it is so huge! Starts with Byzantine beginnings and ends with modern. A must-see in St. Petersburg!

State Russian Museum, St Petersburg former Petrograd, Leningrad. As everyone know is this the finest museum in the town if you are interested in russian paintings from the time before the revolution and after.Why visit The Eremitage where you are among thousends of other visitors daily ? A few travelers understand to choose Russian Museum instead of the Eremitage I belive ? I use to travel to russia every year and every time I go there because of the reason I explained.

One of the best Arts museum in the world. This museum has a superb collection of many Russians genius artists from the 18th - 20th centures. Among the artists Aivazovsky, Kuindghi, Surikov, Repin, Levitan, Brullov. The Russian Museum today is a unique depository of artistic treasures.

My favorite museum in St. Petersburg. I go to the State Russian Museum because it is all about Russian art, every era from early icons to the constructivst era to contemporary art. It is laid out by period, and there is new explanatory material for a number of the exhibits. Also check out the rooms devoted to traditional crafts.

art gallery. The museum is the Mikhailovsky Palace, the main exposure and has several branches in St. Petersburg. The museum features Russian artists such as Rublev, Shubin, Levitsky, Repin, Vrubel, Malevich, Kandinsky, Chagall and others.

Fantastic Museam of Strickly Russian Art. After the Hermitage which is international in nature, this museam must not be missed. Fine examples of very exquisite paintings of the russian masters. Tastful interior and great value. give yourself at least 4 yrs for a superficial visit a full day if you really want to take in the views. Extra to be able to take photos without flash. Try that in a western museum!
A must visit for Russian history, art, culture!!. You will never experience this culture elsewhere. A must visit in StP!

A little of modern Russia. Art from after the Rev. For the most part. Does have a few rooms of older items but the interesting work is the more current work. Don't give up on he maze of rooms press on!
Wonderful. Russian art arranged in chronological order. Really easy to see development through 19th 20th century particularly.
Interesting. It doesn't compare to The Hermitage but it does show art by Russian artists. We even saw some work done under the communist regime. Again, the architecture is a must see.
The best museum in St. Petersburg. It is the best museum in the Northern Capital of Russia. The paintings of famous artists attract visitors from all countries of the world.

One of the great art galleries of the world. This is made up of 5 separate and spread apart buildings each with their own focus so it was confusing to arrive at the one we wanted. We wanted the Modern Russian Art one and it is both amazing and fascinating and big. Some stuff not as fully represented as I would have liked though - Socialist Realism and the Structuralists for example and there is very little indication of the output of young contemporaries - such of the moment stuff that there was was in a special show and was very laboured, pretty-pretty and sentimental. But nowhere is perfect and there is so much and so varied great and sometimes famous stuff (painting, a little sculpture and a tiny bit of video) to see and it is all well laid out and well lit and there are nice art history type wall texts in Russian and English to introduce each section. There was a big contemporary photo show at one of the other buildings, but we did not have the time to get to it.
superb. wonderful Pete - one of those places you HAVE TO go visit

Amazing art. I am proud to say I had a pleasure of seeing this amazing Russian art which I know and have learned so little because it's not so represented in Europe. Truly a must see if you want to close in to the Russian tradition and art. For using a camera you need to pay extra. Take your time and see this attraction, you won't regret it. And when you see Kazimir's Black Square you will laugh in yourself how much it is simple, but brilliant and original. Just don't laugh loudly, you will get some strange looks :)

Small & Manageable but boring without a guide or audio help. Credit card connection not working so we paid cash. Required to check coats and backpacks - and pay extra to use camera. It's a maze to find the same point at which you checked in. Art has no language barriers - Russian art to me is indistinguishable from other countries. I'm illiterate in art appreciation.

A Good Permanent Exhibit. The chronologically placed permanent collection of 20th Century Russian art allowed me to better understand its development. There are ever-changing temporary exhibits as well. A suggestion: use the entrance by the canal rather than the main entrance, if you wish to see the works of the 19th and 20th centuries. Otherwise it is a very long walk from the building with the earlier works.
Manageable & Lovely. Russian art is beautiful & largely unknown in the west. Be prepared for some wonderful surprises. The Accoustiguide is recommended as the explanations are excellent.

One of a kind collection of Russian art. Was here in July 2010 during the freat heatwave in Russia. Had a private guide, Olga. This museum is my fav in Petersburg, more than the Hermitage. It is much smaller (but not small!). And its artworks highlight Russian artists exclusively, most unknown to the West. Had my notebook with me, and learned so much about these artists and their paintings. Serov, Filonov, Schedrin, Venetsianov, Repin, and others. I would rank this museum on par with the Orsay in Paris, for its sheer sublimity in displaying exclusively Russian art. Highly recommended, and yet, off the radar for most tourists.

Excellent. St. Petersburg it is not all about the Hermitage. It is little known that the Hermitage houses almost no significant Russian artworks, therefore if you want to see Russian artworks you have to go to the Russian Museum.The Museum dominates the beautiful Arts Square, also home to the Mikhailovsky Theatre, the Great Philarmonic Hall and the venerable Hotel Europe.The collections are impressive, and you can get lost in visiting them. I found the collection of Soviet Art especially interesting and challenging. But there is much more. Fellow travelers, make sure not to miss this fantastic Museum!

A true gem of Russian Culture. The Hermitage normally attracts all the attention since it's a world-renowned museum, so The Russian Museum gets side-tracked, which is a pity. I think it's always good to get a flavour of the authentic culture of the country one travels to. A comprehensive collection of Russian art is housed in sumptuous yet elegant palace. Genuine Russian Icons, masterful landscapes and a range of paintings on classical plots by the russian artists are true gems. The exhibitions give fantastic insights into the country's rich cultural heritage to say nothing about art lover's pleasure.
Art you don't see outside Russia. Fascinating to see beautiful works of art that you won't see elsewhere.
State Russian Museum. Lovely grounds, but almost swamped by the grandeur of The Hermitage.
The history of russian art. Russia is worldwide known for its artists, and here you can see a lot of them under one roof. Don't forget to visit The Benois Wing.

certainly a must. perhaps a half day might be enough for everyone. Not too interested by the Russian folk art. Beware the place is bigger than you think. THe Malevitch and co are worth the trip of course
A glimpse into the Russian psyche. This museum is all about being Russian and some of the older art work is quite touching and evocative.
Visit it. Here you will see items related to Russian artists and great paintings and icons, do not miss a visit

A gallery well worth visiting. Not as large as the Hermitage but still enormous. Definitely the place to see Russian art. We tried to see bits of it in less than an hour but it was too big for that. You need at least a couple of hours to do it any justice.
Interesting art. Interesting art but I preferred the Hermitage and visiting the Churches

Great place to experience Russian culture. The Russian Museum today is one of the major cultural and educational centers in Russia, and a research and instructional centre of art museums of the Russian Federation, overseeing activities of 260 art museums in Russia.Currently there are several exhibition that will last till mid February. The first one ‘From Moscow to the country’s outskirts’ . The exhibition is devoted to the Russian art of the 18th - beginning of the 21 centuries where the significant and versatile theme of outskirt received the various interpretation. The exposition includes about 100 paintings, graphic works, sculptures and applied art works from the collection of the Russian Museum. Another one is devoted to famous Russian painters ‘Collections of Mikhail and Sergei Botkin’. The exhibition consists of two independent parts that sufficiently fully present the gatherings of Mikhail Botkin (1839-1914) and Sergey Botkin (1859-1910) who were the greatest collectors of art works in Russia in the second half of the 19th - beginning of the 20th century.
do not miss it. The museum is beautiful on the outside and inside. There are some of the most famous paintings by Russian artists in it.

Wonderful Art in a Beautiful Building. I wandered into this museum because it was in the guide book not intending to stay all that long. I ended up staying two hours, there's an enormous collection of art from various periods all very well laid out in a beautiful palace. Definitely worth a visit.

Must see. A real surprise. I was advised to go by a Russian colleague and have visited the museum 3 times since that time. Please go and visit the Russian museum and see the paintings of Ilya Repin. What a great artist!

Confusing but enjoyable. A rather eclectic assemblage of exhibits, arranged with absolute daubs set alongside fine works. Also a most confusing set of buildings and linking stairs. Could have been disappointing but the certainty and optimism of so many Russian works made it an uplifting experience.
Now that's what i call a museum!. I've been to maby museums in many countries, Paris, Vienna, Madrid and New york amongst them but this is the biggest and most spectacular. Amazing!

A Copious Collection of Outstanding Russian Art. I spent several days this week enjoying its very extensive collection of Russian Art.This museum has many Russian icons,splendid examples of Russian Folk Art,and an encyclopedic collection of Russian paintings from the Baroque Period(Ivan Nikitin,Fyodor Rokotov)up to the Twenty-first Century.Personal favorites at this huge art museum were;Konstantin Flavitsky's"Christian Martyts in Colisseum",Isaac Levitan's"Twilight Moon".Mikhail Nesterov's"Hermit".Boris Kustodiev's"Shrovetide".Marc Chagall's"Promenade"and Zenaida Serebryakova's"Bath House".This art museum is open on Mondays,but closed on Tuesdays.There is plenty of labelling in English and sincere spasibas to their staff for being so kind and helpful.

The best museum. This is my favorite museum in St. Petersburg. I prefer it to the Hermitage. The Hermitage is great and you must see it on your first tour. But the Russian museum is unique, has fantastic art (all Russian as you can guess from its name), and much less crowded. Enjoy!

Don't Miss This!. Nowhere near as famous as the Hermitage but the art is not to be missed. Some incredibly large and deeply beautiful paintings, especially the one of the storm at sea and the one of the boatmen pulling a river boat with straps and human power.

Impressive collection but staff cost a star. Was very impressed by the pieces on exhibit, however, entrance staff weren't helpful and those inside the museumndidn't even speak basic English and couldn't help with queries. Still, delighted i could see this on my trip to Russia but they don't make the process very easy for a foreigner

after the Hermitage.... Everyone with an interest in fine art and architecture makes the Hermitage an indispensable part of a visit to St. Petersburg. Far fewer Western tourists allow time for a visit to this extraordinary palace/gallery, where the most amazing treasures of Russian art are housed. I cannot recommend this place highly enough, as it is clearly among the finest places of its kind in the world. The Hermitage offers great European art from every country and period, but the State Museum gives one a very special impression of the greatest Russian painters and sculptors.

Amazing experience. This museums has really outstanding collection, spacing between centuries, and the quality of the works is so high! I especially appreciated the avant-guards of XX century, a great exhibition with perfect lights, took many pictures to save the memories. Again, I paid extra ticket for photography but nobody checked it. The museum is really a must-see in my opinion, beyond the Ermitage.
Don't miss!. I am very pleased I did find time to go to the Russian Museum. It was excellent collections of Russian artists. I was very impressed! Just WOW!

Loved the manageable size, loved the art, loved the lack of crowds. Enjoyed this visit more than the Hermitage. Loved the concentration on just Russian art. The museum wasn't too crowded, or too big. Less stressful, more leisurely visit. Highly recommend.
The Russian Stuff. It's the place to go to see the local Russian artists; many of whom I'd never come across. Don't just rely on a visit to the Hermitage.

Better than I expected. Since the museum is almost entirely Russian Art and artifacts I didn't know if I would like it that much. However, the museum is a cultural lesson in Russian art and life and I thought is was almost as great as the Hermitage. There are some amazing religious painting of epic size and although those aren't usually what I like, here I did. Even though you probably don't know of more than Kandinsky, the talent is of top quality.
Average Museum. Nothing particular to highlight if you are short of time you may skip it.
Very interesting. I really enjoyed the museum, although some of the exhibits did not have any English explanations. The audioguide was helpful.
great. this place houses the best collection of portraits I've seen untill now

Don't Miss this Gem. This collection of Russian art, especially paintings, is unmatched and mostly unknown outside Russia. The main collection of paintings is from 19th and 20th Century artists who rebelled against traditional, safe forms that emphasized mythic subjects and heroic events in order to portray real life. Many of the later works were also influenced by the Impressionist Movement.

Remarkable and worth visiting. Thsi museum is not as highly sought after as the Hermitage however some of the exhibits are equally as good.The entrance is below ground to the side and kind of hard to find. Once inside it is filled with remarkable art and treasures and we were so happy to have gone.Some of the art is astounding and the building itself incredible. You do not need the same amount of time as the Herimatge so it's worth checking out and we would rate it a 5 as well for different reasons.

Amazing paintings you've never seen. . Although I have knowledge of art, I had never heard of most of these artists, but the paintings are created by talented people who rival those we know in the West. I assume that the fact that Russians weren't permitted access to the West kept word of these Russian painters within Russia, If you have any interest in art, you should see this museum.

For a concentrated Russian experience.... After the Hermitage this museum focuses mainly on Russian artists. It does not have the magnificence or the square footage but is packed with Russian history. Currently closed on Tuesdays as Russia alternates museum closed days to ensure there is always something to do. Best to avoid the museums on the weekends as they are always busy.

Awesome. Really really.. Students get in cheaper here. Flash your student card (it doesn't have to be an ISIC). The rooms are numbered coherently and you can really see how Russian art evolved over the years. Also, unlike the Ermitage every painting has a label in English alongside the Russian, with a short description of the painting that allows an unknowledgeable person like me to understand what was going on. Take the map which shows the floorplan of the museum and start from upstairs. The museum wardens (do you call them that!)/the ladies sitting in each room are atypical and will actually greet you back with a smile when you say zdrastvooyte to them (: For someone looking to be exposed to Russian art the Russian Museum cannot come recommended enough. I guess the Hermitage is a must-see but it can get overcrowded, and frankly I don't want to see so much of western European Art when I've traveled specially to Russia, even if some of its artists are indeed influenced by italian art...
favorite museum in St Petersburg. Gave real insight into the Russian character, values, political experience.

I loved this museum.. The museum is beautiful on the outside and inside. There are some of the most famous paintings by Russian artists in it. Just to name a few of my favorites: paintings by Ilya Repin "Bargemen on the Volga", "Sadko in the Underwater Kingdom", and "Zaporozhye Cossaks"; Karl Brullov's "The Last Day of Pompeii"; the original painting by Ivanov "The Appearance of Christ to the People" (it is though much smaller than the gigantic painting by Ivanov in Tretyakov's gallery; but this smaller one was the one he spent 20 years working on and only after that he painted the gigantic version). I wish we had more time in thsi museum. You definitely need at least two-three hours to see all the highlights.

GREAT MUSEUM, DO NOT MISS IT. It has been an amazing experiences to visit this museum.I have had the opportunity to discover painters that I never heard of before.It is not so overwhelming as Hermitage Museum.... and it is really beautiful.Really, it is not so often that one discovers painters that have fascinating paintings and are completely new to me and I am sure to many other people.

If you love the Hermitage, do not pass this up!. 45 minutes was definitely not enough for this place! If time had permitted I would have revisited this musuem. Halls of equal grandeur as the Hermitage. Artwork by russian artists are pretty amazing, especially love Vasily Perov and Ivan Kramskoi (actually these were the only ones I rem, I'm sure there are many more amazing artists). Other than paintings, there are many many sculptures to admire too!Do not pass up!

Underrated, But Gorgeous Museum. Do not pass up on seeing this incredible museum, it really does an excellent job in showing the Russian culture throughout history and the contributions Russians made to the art community. This museum is filled with the well known and lesser known artist, but is also has many beautiful handcarved wood and bone relics. While the Hermitage gets all the glory, this museum is definitely worth the visit; it will certainly help give a better appreciation of the Russian culture. In fact, some of the pieces are a marvel just by their size alone. We went mid-week, during the day and while the crowds at times were a little heavy, for the most part they were quite sparse in comparison to other sites. This is another museum that's best to leave the jackets and bags behind, or your going to be stuck checking it all in.

From icons to avant-garde to Russian folk art.. While the Hermitage is hailed as the most important Petersburg museum, the State Russian Museum is definitely number one when it comes to purely Russian art.The collection includes some of the oldest Russian icons, a walk through the mainstream Russian paintings including works by Wrubel and Riepin and by avant-garde artists like Malevich (his Red Cavalry and Red Square are displayed just like that, on on the wall in the corner of a small room with no specific reverence). There are also a number of folk art collections, moss figurines for children being my favorite.It's cheap, it's close to the center and it's really worth it. Just watch out when planning your visit here as the museum and the neighboring park could sometimes be closed without prior notice as it seems to be *the* place for the societe's parties (read: fireworks, militia blocking out half of the city center etc.).

Hermitage gets all the press, but don't pass a chance to visit this museum. We were very pleasantly surprised with the Russian Museum. Even after seeing the Hermitage first, we found this collection more than worth our time and attention. This is a top 5 for us in St. Petersburg, no question.

Do the Hermitage - but don't skip the Russian Museum!. Our original itinerary was to skip the Russian Museum and only see the Hermitage, but our Russian friends insisted that we see the Russian Museum. And boy were they right! The museum collects Russian artwork from the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Most of the greatest Russian artists are unknown outside of Russia, so if you're like us, you've never heard of artists like Repin and Surikov. But their works are collected here - and they are AMAZING. There's something about seeing great art that blows you away that you've never ever heard about before. We felt like we were somehow discovering these gems. Unlike the Hermitage, it's not difficult to get inside and not crowded at all (except maybe the downstairs coat check area). The Hermitage is unmissable, but don't think "one museum is enough." You'd be doing yourself a disservice.

Incredible Art in a beautiful setting.. Not far from Palace Square (and surrounded by decent restaurants), is the most excellent Mikhaelovski Palace more commonly known as the Russian Museum. This was my second favorite museum in Russia - behind only the Hermitage. First of all, it's in a palace beautiful in its own right. Second, you're not as likely to be subject to the mass crowds at the Hermitage. (Although you will run into the occasional tour gruop or students led by a teacher)Most importantly, it is filled with beautiful art by artists you've likely never heard of. Some you may have, if you've studied Russian history (Repin and the like), but Schedrin, Ivazovski, Roerich - the list goes on and on. This isn't just boring icons -beautiful seascapes, modern art and excellent impressionism is intermixed with your standard portraits and well-done marble work. When you leave you're treated to a beautiful view of the Church on Spilled Blood (Spas na Kravi) to your right.The two of them followed by an excellent Georgian restaurant make for a day well-spent.
